months ended June 30, 2023, we reversed the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €1.1 million for the period. In
June 2022, we, together with our joint venture partner, decided to sell Fortrent. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum,
our interest in Fortrent continues to be held for sale. See also "—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment—
_Our business is subject to various legal and regulatory compliance risks, including those involving antitrust, anti-money_
_laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations and sanctions."_

We are actively monitoring the situation in Ukraine and Russia and assessing its impact on our business. The
extent and duration of the military action, sanctions and resulting market disruptions could be significant and could
potentially have a substantial impact on the global economy and our business for an unknown period of time. Although we
do not have any current activities in Russia or Ukraine, we have activities in Scandinavia, Poland and the Baltic States, and
if the conflict intensifies or expands beyond Ukraine, it could have an adverse impact on our business. For example, we
may be forced to reorganize, reduce or terminate business operations in geographical areas where our employees, partners
or subcontractors would otherwise be subject to unacceptable economic or personal risks, which could have an adverse
effect on our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.


-----

**_We may not be able to execute our growth strategy._**

We have historically expanded our business through a combination of strategic acquisitions and organic growth.
Our growth strategy depends in part on our ability to identify attractive acquisition candidates and successfully integrate
them into our business. Acquisitions are subject to several risks and there can be no assurance that we will be able to
identify attractive acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at
commercially acceptable prices or terms. In particular, our industry is experiencing rapid consolidation which could impact
our ability to achieve our strategy. See also "—The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through
_acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business." Our growth strategy also depends in part on our ability to_
successfully identify and open new depots, both in countries where we already have an established presence as well as
other countries to which we may decide to expand in the future. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify
attractive new depot locations and successfully open and operate them. Opening new depots requires significant
investments and management attention and may involve risks associated with entering new markets, including markets
where we face significant competition. We may not have sufficient management, financial and other resources to
successfully identify and operate such new depots. Any significant diversion of management's attention, unexpected cost
associated with or any major difficulties encountered in acquiring new businesses or operating new depots could have a
material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows, and make it more difficult
for us to achieve our strategy. Furthermore, general economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets
could affect the timing and extent to which we can make strategic acquisitions and open new depots, which could materially
adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

Furthermore, the success of our strategy, in particular with respect to organic growth, depends on our ability to
accurately forecast trends. Our decisions about investments in new equipment, for example, are based in significant part
on our views of future demand, and any failure to accurately predict demand could negatively affect our growth prospects.
If anticipated growth does not occur, we may not earn the level of returns that we hope to achieve on investments made
during the bottom of the cycle. Alternatively, if growth is greater than expected, we may not have a fleet of appropriate
size and mix. More generally, uncertainty regarding future product demand in the markets in which we operate, or markets
in which we seek to enter, could cause us to maintain excess equipment inventory and increase our capital expenditures
beyond what is efficient. Alternatively, this forecasting difficulty could cause a shortage of equipment for rental that could
result in an inability to satisfy demand for our products and a loss of market share which could in turn materially adversely
affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_The success of our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into_**
**_our business._**

Historically, we have achieved growth in part through acquisitions and our strategy assumes that some future
growth will occur inorganically, through further acquisitions of businesses that we believe complement or enhance our
existing products, services, markets, capabilities or technologies. For example, in February 2020, we acquired Cramo Plc
("Cramo"), a provider of equipment rental and modular space solutions and greatly expanded our operations in the Nordics.
Although the integration of the Cramo business into our Central Europe region is largely complete, we are continuing to
undertake significant integration projects with respect to management structures and back-office functions, through our
various "One-projects", including One-Finance, One-Fleet, One-HR and One-IT. A failure to successfully execute any of
these integration projects on time, on budget and as envisaged could materially adversely affect our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows. There can be no assurance that we will be able to identify attractive
acquisition candidates in the future or complete the acquisition of any identified candidates at favorable prices or on
advantageous terms. We expect to face competition for acquisition candidates, which may limit the number of acquisition
opportunities we have and lead to higher acquisition costs. We may not have the financial resources necessary to
consummate any acquisitions or the ability to obtain the necessary funds on satisfactory terms. Furthermore, general
economic conditions or unfavorable global capital and credit markets could affect the timing and extent to which we
successfully acquire new businesses.

In general, the risks associated with acquisitions, which could materially adversely affect our business, results of
operations, financial condition and cash flows, include the following:

    - we may lose sales and incur substantial costs, delays or other operational or financial problems in
integrating acquired businesses and integration may be more costly and take longer than expected;

    - we may not achieve financial and operational synergies on a timely basis or without significant costs, if
at all;

    - acquisitions may divert management's attention from the operation of the existing business;


-----

    - the assumptions underlying the business plans supporting the valuations of the acquisitions and expected
synergies may prove inaccurate, in particular with respect to the future performance of the acquired
businesses;

    - we may be forced to divest or reduce the scope of certain businesses to obtain the necessary regulatory
authorizations, in particular with respect to anti-trust authorizations;

    - we may need to write down goodwill and certain other intangible assets from our balance sheet if our
initial estimates of the value of an acquired business are higher than actual results;

    - we may be further exposed to risks of fluctuations in currency exchange rates;

    - we may not be able to retain key personnel of an acquired company, which could lead to loss of
institutional knowledge and customer relationships;

    - we may not be able to retain existing customers of the acquired business;

    - we may experience corporate or market cannibalization;

    - we may face increased competition;

    - we may operate an acquired company as a joint venture with partners with whom we lack a longstanding
relationship; and

    - we may encounter unanticipated events, circumstances or liabilities related to the acquired businesses,
their integration and the growth of our business, particularly in geographic areas in which we have not
previously operated.

In addition to the risks described above, the integration of acquired businesses may be more difficult and take
more time due to logistical, regulatory, linguistic, cultural and other factors such as our relative lack of familiarity with a
given market and its economic, political and social dynamics. If we are not successful in implementing our acquisition
strategy or integrating such acquisitions, or if some or all of our existing or future acquisitions prove ultimately to be
unsuccessful, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

**_We depend on equipment manufacturers to obtain adequate rental equipment for our fleet on a timely basis._**

We purchase most of our rental equipment from well-known original equipment manufacturers. We rely on our
relationships with original equipment manufacturers to centralize our procurement and benefit from economies of scale.
Failure to maintain these relationships, or successfully optimize our economies of scale in the future, could lead to higher
unit costs for our procurement and present availability issues due to shortages of material or components such as
microchips. As we do not manufacture any of the products that we rent to our customers, we rely on third-party suppliers
for the provision of the equipment, tools, spare parts and consumables that are essential to our business. However, our
suppliers may not be able to fulfill the terms of their agreements with us on a timely basis or at all for logistical or strategic
reasons, including issues affecting the global supply chain generally as a result of economic disruption. Further, suppliers
may be unwilling to extend contracts that provide favorable terms to us, or they may seek to renegotiate existing contracts
with us. As a result, we could face increased costs for our equipment or longer delivery times.

Delays in the delivery of new equipment may impair our ability to respond to increases in demand, put us at a
disadvantage to our competitors and may cause us to miss opportunities in our markets. For instance, equipment
manufacturers have recently faced and continue to face supply chain difficulties, in particular with respect to the raw
materials needed to manufacture chips and batteries, and as a result, we have recently experienced, and continue to
experience, delays in deliveries of purchased equipment. In addition, delays in delivery can adversely affect our equipment
maintenance and relocation costs, as there may no longer be local demand for the purchased equipment by the time it
arrives at the point of delivery. We may experience further delays or an inability to source new equipment on a timely basis
or at all. We may not be able to find alternative sources of supply for the equipment we purchase in each of our core product
categories, and the termination or delay of equipment orders by a major supplier could adversely affect our business. If we
are required to procure more costly equipment, our business could be adversely affected if we are not able to pass the cost
increases of such equipment through to our customers. Furthermore, while our top 10 suppliers at Group level only
represented approximately 11.1% of our total expenditure for the year ended December 31, 2022, our procurement
processes could be negatively affected if our business relationships with any of our top 10 suppliers are disrupted, which,
in turn, could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.


-----

Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

**_The cost of equipment purchases for our rental fleet, in addition to other operating costs, may increase._**

The cost of new equipment that we purchase for our rental fleet may increase as a result of a number of factors,
including increased raw material costs (such as costs of steel), scarcity of component parts necessary to manufacture our
rental equipment (such as microchips and batteries), increased labor costs, inflation generally or geopolitical developments
and other world events. For example, the Russian invasion of Ukraine destabilized the financial and commodity markets
and resulted in an uncertain macroeconomic situation in Europe, causing inflation throughout the economy, rises in interest
rates and volatile energy prices and such factors have had, and could have in the future, an adverse effect on the cost of
new equipment we purchase for our rental fleet.

In particular, the cost of steel, which is a primary material used in most of our equipment and products, rose
sharply in 2021 as countries around the world began to recover from the economic downturn caused by COVID-19 and
has continued to rise following the commencement of hostilities between Russia and Ukraine due to a combination of
sanctions against Russian producers and disruptions of production in Ukraine. While additional capacity currently exists
that can replace the foregoing volumes, increases in the spot prices of steel in Europe may nonetheless persist. Further
increases in prices of raw materials could cause the price of new equipment to rise, which could materially affect our
business to the extent that we are not able to pass such cost increases through to our customers.

In addition, we are subject to risks related to the increases in energy or transportation costs. Energy prices are in
turn subject to significant volatility caused by, among other things, inflation, market fluctuations, supply and demand,
currency fluctuations, production and transportation disruptions, tariffs, resource availability, geopolitical developments
and other world events, as well as climate change related conditions and other factors beyond our control. High energy and
transportation costs could increase the price of new equipment purchases, which could adversely affect our business.
Additionally, higher energy and transportation costs could significantly increase our operating costs. In 2022, partially as
a result of the increase in fuel prices stemming from the conflict in Ukraine, we saw a significant increase in our logistics
costs compared to prior years. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in minimizing our logistics costs
through our hub-and-spoke logistics model or in passing along such costs to our customers. Any future increases in our
logistics costs could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operation and cash flows.

Changes in customer demand due to changed technology, safety or environmental concerns, regulations, or other
factors could cause certain of our existing equipment to become obsolete and require us to purchase new equipment, which
would increase our costs. Further, electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment each have a purchasing cost which is
significantly higher than similar equipment using older and less environmentally friendly engines. Purchasing electric,
hybrid and battery powered equipment also incurs costs associated with training our employees and customers on the use,
maintenance, safety requirements, and repair of the new technology. Due to the significantly higher purchasing costs of
electric, hybrid and battery powered equipment our capital expenditure is expected to increase in the future. There can be
no assurances that potential maintenance costs savings will offset the expected increase in capital expenditure. These factors
in turn could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_The effective management, maintenance and repair of our rental fleet is vital to our business._**

Our rental equipment has a long economic life, and managing this equipment is a critical element to our rental
business. Rental equipment asset management requires that we build up and maintain an inventory of durable, high-quality
products that anticipate the needs of our customers and changes in technology, legislation, regulations, building codes and
local permitting in the various markets in which we operate. In addition, we must successfully maintain and repair this
equipment cost-effectively to maximize the economic life of the products and, to a lesser extent, the proceeds that may be
received from the sale of these products. As the needs of our customers change, we may need to incur costs to relocate or
retrofit our rental assets to better meet shifts in demand, beyond relocations that occur in the ordinary course of business to
maximize fleet uptime and address customer demand. In addition, if the location of our assets is not efficiently coordinated
with regional demand, we may incur costs from relocating the fleet (which includes costs associated with local regulatory
compliance, as well as transportation and storage) or we may be unable to take advantage of business opportunities despite
excess inventory in other regions. If we are not able to successfully manage our rental assets, our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

In addition, where we have contracts that employ the use of our rental equipment for long durations, we may be
exposed to the risk that our costs increase materially over the term of the project, whether due to inflation, rising interest
rates or adverse movements in currency exchange rates, and we are unable to pass on those cost increases to such customers
where fixed pricing has been agreed. If the project is significant (or if there are one or more issues that impact multiple
projects) or experiences cost overruns, delays or issues with the quality or availability of supplies, any of these may have
a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.


-----

As the equipment in our rental fleet ages, the cost of maintaining such equipment, if not replaced within a certain
period of time, generally increases, and we may be unable to pass along such costs to customers. Determining the optimal
average age for disposal of our rental fleet is subjective and requires considerable estimates by management. Additionally,
maintenance of newer, electric and hybrid equipment may be costlier than the maintenance cost of older gas- and dieselpowered equipment, which could adversely affect our business if we are unable to pass those costs through to our customers.
Our future operating results could be adversely affected because our maintenance and repair costs may be higher than
estimated, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash
flows.

**_We are dependent on our executives, managers and employees._**

Our success depends, to a large degree, upon the continued effort and abilities of our existing management team,
including our CEO and principal ultimate shareholder, Mr. Pierre Boels Jr. Our senior management team has significant
experience in the industries and markets in which we operate. If we lose the services of any key member of our senior
management team and are unable to find a suitable replacement in a timely manner, it may be a challenge for us to
effectively manage our business and execute our strategy.

Our success also depends on the experience and skills of our country and operational managers, district and area
managers and depot managers, who have extensive knowledge of our business and industry experience. Competition for
managers within our industry is generally significant, and, if any of our senior or regional managers joins a competitor or
forms a competing company, we may lose customers, know-how and other personnel.

In addition, we depend upon the quality of our staff personnel, including sales and customer service personnel
who routinely interact with and fulfill the needs of our customers. There can be no assurance that we will be able to continue
to attract, hire, train and retain qualified personnel, especially in the tight labor markets we currently face in most of the
countries in which we operate or that we will not face increases in personnel expenses in line with, or above, inflation. A
significant increase in personnel turnover or costs could negatively affect our results of operations and financial
performance. Any of the above factors could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

**_Damage to our reputation and our brand could adversely affect our business._**

We believe that we have developed a reputation and brand images associated with a high-quality fleet of rental
equipment, customer service, reliability and social and environmental responsibility. Our brand names, trademarks and
logos, as well as their respective reputation are valuable and powerful sales and marketing tools. Litigation, employee
misconduct or the misconduct of anyone associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands), operational failures,
accidents, the outcome of regulatory investigations, press speculation and negative publicity, disclosure of customer
information, inadequate products and services, among others, could all affect our brand or reputation. Although our
customers are generally responsible for the way in which they handle our rental equipment and despite our efforts to
promote training and safety, accidents involving our equipment can and do occur, which can have an impact on the
perceived image of our brands. Furthermore, the Boels brand is perceived to be strongly connected to our CEO, Pierre
Boels Jr. and his family. Should Pierre Boels Jr. and his family cease to be connected to the Boels brand, for example,
through exiting the business, our customer goodwill related to the Boels brand may decline. We are also exposed to the
risk that individuals associated with the Boels brand (or any of our other brands) take actions that may affect our brand or
reputation. The occurrence of any of the above risks could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Disruptions in our information technology systems could limit our capacity to effectively monitor and control our_**
**_operations._**

We rely on information technology systems to track and bill our services, manage our fleet, meet our customers'
needs and gather information upon which our management makes decisions regarding our business. Our information
technology systems also facilitate our ability to adjust to changing market conditions. The administration of our business
is increasingly reliant on the use of IT systems and artificial intelligence to digitalize processes and systems. The risk of a
security breach or disruption, particularly through a cyber-attack or cyber intrusion, has risen as the number, intensity and
sophistication of attempted attacks and intrusions around the world have increased. Additionally, due to the significant
efforts to digitalize our business, an increasingly larger amount of data is stored in IT systems and vulnerable to data
security breaches. Our information technology systems may not be fully protected against such third-party intrusions or
against viruses, ransom ware, or similar threats. Disruptions resulting from these threats, system crashes or other causes
could have a material adverse effect on our business. In particular, we use several ERP systems across our network and
any disruption to our ERP systems, or the failure of any of these systems to operate as expected could, depending on the
magnitude of the problem, adversely affect our operating results. We back-up most of our data daily, train our employees
in this regard, perform penetration testing and have a disaster recovery plan in place for most of our systems, including our


-----

ERP system. However, our disaster recovery plan does not cover all of our systems. Our back-up systems may fail, and
any recovery of our data may be incomplete or subject to delay.

In addition, because our systems may contain information about individuals and businesses, our failure to
appropriately safeguard the security of the data we hold, whether as a result of our own error or the malfeasance or errors
of others, could harm our reputation or give rise to legal liabilities. In most of the regions in which we operate, the
processing of personal data is subject to governmental regulation and legislation. Any failure to comply with such
regulations or legislation could lead to governmental sanctions, including fines or the initiation of criminal or civil
proceedings. In the European Union, we must comply with strict data protection and privacy laws that restrict our ability
to collect and use personal information relating to customers and potential customers, including the marketing use of that
information. In particular, Regulation (EU) 2016/679 of April 27, 2016 (known as the "General Data Protection
**Regulation" or "GDPR"), which became applicable on May 25, 2018, increased both the number of and the restrictive**
nature of the obligations binding on us for the collection and processing of personal data. Additionally, we are subject to
the supervision of relevant data protection authorities under the GDPR and, with respect to our operations in the United
Kingdom, the United Kingdom General Data Protection Regulation and Data Protection Act 2018 (the "UK GDPR"), and
could be fined under each of those regimes independently in respect of the same breach. Although we collect and store a
limited amount of personal data, and have proper registrations in place, failure to comply with the provisions of GDPR or
UK GDPR could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our business and reputation may be adversely affected by the actions of third parties._**

In our business, we rely on third-party partners for the provision of certain services, such as collections, IT systems
and transport services. If a partner is unable to deliver its services or a supplier is unable to deliver equipment according to
the pre-agreed terms or in a timely manner, our reputation may suffer, and we may be required to purchase such goods or
services from another source at a higher price. We may not be able to recover all of these costs in all circumstances, which
may reduce the profit expected to be realized under such agreements or result in a loss. Moreover, if we purchase services
from a third party that is not one of our ordinary providers, there is a risk that we may fail to deliver such services at the
quality standards that our customers have been accustomated to, which could be detrimental to our reputation and our
relationships with our customers.

While we carefully monitor internal and external developments for areas of potential reputational risk, and have
established governance structures to assist in evaluating such risks in our business practices and decisions, we may be
affected by the inappropriate, fraudulent, negligent, unauthorized or criminal activities of third parties, including
employees, suppliers, customers and subcontractors, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial
condition, results of operations and cash flows. We may be exposed to fraud or other misconduct committed by our
employees, representatives, agents, customers or other third parties that could affect our reputation and subject us to
litigation, financial  losses and regulatory action. Such misconduct could include hiding unauthorized or unlawful
activities resulting in unknown and unmanaged risks of losses, theft of equipment, improperly using or disclosing
confidential information, misappropriating funds, engaging in misrepresentation or fraudulent, deceptive or otherwise
improper activities or otherwise failing to comply with applicable laws or our internal policies and procedures. Actions
taken by third-party partners acting as our agents may also subject us to vicarious liability suits.

Additionally, our digitalization strategy requires us to increasingly rely on third-party providers to maintain our
IT systems and to perform certain core business processes for our websites, ERP tools, asset monitoring and maintenance
systems, online platforms and data systems. Outsourcing these processes exposes us to various risks, such as loss of control,
data breaches, service disruptions, quality issues, contractual disputes and increased costs. We may not be able to monitor,
manage, or remedy the performance or compliance of our IT service providers effectively or in a timely manner. We may
also face difficulties in finding alternative or backup IT service providers in the event of termination, dissatisfaction, or
insolvency of our current IT service providers. Failure to maintain our IT systems could materially adversely affect our
business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

**_Seasonality and severe weather conditions may cause fluctuations and disruptions in our business._**

Our revenue and operating results have historically varied from period to period. In particular, many of the markets
in which our customers operate are characterized by seasonal cycles causing our operations to experience a degree of
seasonality in the first quarter of each year, driven principally by climatic conditions in our different regions of operations.
Demand in the civil engineering, construction, infrastructure and other industrial markets tends to decrease in winter and
during extended periods of inclement weather while increasing in the summer and during extended periods of mild weather.
Additionally, severe weather events, such as storms, floods and blizzards, can suppress activity in the civil engineering,
industrial markets, construction and infrastructure markets, which can adversely impact our business, financial condition,
results of operation and cash flows.


-----

**_We may be subject to liabilities that are not covered by our insurance policies._**

We carry insurance of various types, including but not limited to, property damage insurance, general liability
coverage and directors' liability insurance. We may not always be able to accurately foresee all activities and situations in
order to ensure that they are fully covered by the terms of our insurance policies and, as a result, our insurance may not
cover such risks adequately or at all. While we seek to maintain appropriate levels of insurance, not all claims are insurable,
and we may experience incidents of a nature that are not covered by insurance. Any significant uninsured liability may
require us to pay substantial amounts, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

Further, we may be exposed to multiple claims that do not exceed our deductibles, and, as a result, we could incur
significant out-of-pocket costs that could adversely affect our financial condition and results of operations. In addition, the
cost of our insurance policies may increase upon renewal of those policies as a result of general rate increases for the type
of insurance we carry as well as our historical experience and experience in our industry. Our current insurance policies
may not continue to be available in the future on economically reasonable terms, or at all. If we are required to pay
significantly higher premiums for insurance or are not able to maintain insurance coverage at affordable rates, we could
experience higher costs that could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our rental fleet is subject to residual value risk upon disposition._**

Our approach to fleet management is to replace equipment only at the end of its useful rental life, at which time it
is sold, used for parts or sold for scrap. Usually, a piece of equipment is amortized at least to the level of its residual value
by the time it is removed from the fleet. Nonetheless, the market value of any given piece of rental equipment could be less
than its depreciated value or residual value at the time it is sold. The market value of used rental equipment depends on
several factors, including:

    - general economic conditions;

    - worldwide and domestic demands for used equipment;

    - the supply of used equipment on the market;

    - the market price for new equipment of the same kind;

    - wear and tear on the equipment relative to its age; and

    - technological developments.

Any significant decline in the selling prices for used equipment could have an adverse effect on our business,
financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

**Financial Risks**

**_Unfavorable conditions in the capital and credit markets and political uncertainty may adversely affect business_**
**_conditions and our access to credit needed to maintain and grow our business._**

Disruptions in the global capital and credit markets as a result of an economic downturn, economic uncertainty,
regulatory changes, financial institution failures, armed conflict, pandemics, trade wars or other factors could adversely
affect our ability to access liquidity to invest in our equipment fleet. In addition, bank failures, liquidity concerns and other
adverse developments affecting financial institutions, or rumors about such events, may impact the stability of global
financial markets. In the event of weakening macroeconomic conditions, our customers may face challenges to obtain
financing for their projects from lenders or in the capital and credit markets, which may cause some of our customers to be
unable to meet their payment obligations to us, increasing losses on bad debt. Delinquencies and credit losses generally
can be expected to increase during economic slowdowns or recessions. See "—We are exposed to counterparty risks and
_may incur losses because of such exposure." Moreover, our suppliers may also be adversely impacted by unfavorable_
capital and credit markets, causing disruption to or delay of product deliveries. Political uncertainty may also negatively
impact the capital and credit markets, including through changes in foreign policy or regulatory requirements, trade
restrictions or sanctions, higher tariffs and changes to existing, or the imposition of additional, regulations relating to the
import or export of products. In addition, if the financial institutions that have extended credit commitments to us, or from
which we may seek credit commitments in the future, were to be adversely affected by conditions in the capital and credit
markets, they might be unable or unwilling to fund borrowings under such credit commitments, which could have an


-----

adverse impact on our financial condition and our ability to borrow funds, if needed, for capital expenditures, working
capital, acquisitions, and other corporate purposes.

Global markets are experiencing volatility and disruption as a result of various macroeconomic factors, including
global inflationary pressures and monetary policy tightening, the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, and trade tensions
between the United States and China. Capital markets have been and may continue to be impacted by inflation, which is
currently the case in many of the jurisdictions in which we operate, and there are concerns that current inflationary pressures
could result in significant macroeconomic deterioration, including, but not limited to, decreases in global stock exchange
indices, increased foreign exchange volatility and decreased GDP in the markets in which we operate. In addition, there
are concerns that these events could push the Eurozone, the United Kingdom and/or the United States into an economic
recession, any of which, were they to occur, would further destabilize the global financial markets. Any of the events
described above could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Fluctuations in interest rates could increase our finance costs._**

Material increases in global inflation since early 2022, reaching double-digit levels not seen since the 1980s, and
expectations that annual inflation may remain high for a long period of time (driven in part by the Russian invasion of
Ukraine and the resulting impact on energy markets), have led central banks of the major world economies, including the
U.S. Federal Reserve and the European Central Bank, to significantly increase market interest rates in a short timeframe.
Our finance costs are sensitive to interest rates, exchange rates and other monetary policies of governments and central
banks in the jurisdictions in which we operate.

We and certain of our subsidiaries borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest rates, which exposes us to the
risk of rising interest rates, and on an as adjusted basis after giving effect to the Transactions, a significant amount of our
indebtedness will bear interest at a floating rate. Although we seek to hedge against our interest-bearing liabilities through
interest rate swaps, these instruments may not be effective or available in all circumstances. A sustained increase in inflation
may result in higher interest rates on our borrowings (including finance leases) that are subject to a floating rate of interest,
increasing our financial expenses and cost of borrowing. For example, in the year ended December 31, 2022 and the six
months ended June 30, 2023, we experienced an increase in financial expenses due to the rise in EURIBOR, which resulted
in higher interest payments on our unhedged floating rate borrowings. In addition, we may not be able to refinance such
debt in the future at interest rates that are as favorable as the ones currently applicable to our borrowings. See "—Risks
_Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and Our Structure—Some of our indebtedness, including the Existing Senior_
_Facilities, bears interest at floating rates that could rise significantly, increasing our costs and reducing our cash flow."_

**_Our business could be materially adversely impacted if we are unable to obtain additional capital as required._**

We require capital for, among other things, purchasing rental equipment, opening new branches, expanding our
business, completing acquisitions and refinancing existing debt. Our ability to make principal or interest payments when
due on our indebtedness and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to
generate cash. Our primary sources of cash are cash flows from operating activities and borrowings under our debt facilities,
including our Existing Revolving Credit Facility and our Trade Receivables Purchase Program. This cash may be
insufficient, and we may require additional financing to obtain capital for, among other purposes, operating expenses,
capital expenditures, working capital requirements, acquisitions and debt service payments. Additionally, there is the risk
that our capital expenditures will increase due to ineffective planning of investments or asset sales. See "—Risks related to
_our Business—We may not be able to execute our growth strategy" and "—Risks related to our Business—The success of_
_our strategy depends in part on our ability to grow through acquisitions and integrate acquisitions into our business."_
There can be no assurance that any additional financing that we require will be available or, if available, will be available
on terms that are satisfactory to us.

In addition, in the future, we may need to rely on different sources of financing for our capital expenditures, the
level of which significantly affects the age and size of our equipment fleet, and if we are required to reduce these
expenditures for any reason, the reduced availability of equipment or the age of our rental fleet may cause us competitive
harm and increase our maintenance costs. Any additional indebtedness that we incur will make us more vulnerable to
economic downturns and limit our ability to withstand competitive pressures. If we are unable to obtain sufficient financing,
our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

**_Fluctuations in currency exchange rates could materially and adversely affect our business, financial condition, results_**
**_of operations and cash flows._**

Although we prepare our consolidated financial statements in euro, we derive revenue and incur costs in several
different currencies, including the Swedish krona, the Norwegian krone, the Danish krone, the British pound, the Polish
zloty, Swiss franc and the Czech koruna. Accordingly, movements in exchange rates between any of these currencies and
euro could have an adverse effect on our results of operations to the extent we have a mismatch between our earnings in


-----

any foreign currency and our costs that are denominated in that currency. We also incur currency risk on the net investment
in our subsidiaries in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom.
The results of operations and financial position of these subsidiaries are reported in the relevant functional currency of that
subsidiary. These subsidiaries' assets and liabilities are converted to euro based on the exchange rate on the balance sheet
date, and income statement items are converted to euro based on the average exchange rate during the relevant financial
period. Significant increases in the value of the euro relative to foreign currencies could have a material adverse effect on
our financial position and results of operations. Although we routinely engage in derivative transactions to hedge against
any such fluctuations, there can be no assurance that we will be adequately protected against such risks. For example, our
revenue in the six months ended June 30, 2023 was negatively affected by the weakening of the Swedish krona, Norwegian
krone and the British pound against the euro. If we are exposed to significant adverse movements in foreign currency rates
in the future, our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

**_We are exposed to counterparty risks and may incur losses because of such exposure._**

Although our top 10 customers at Group level only represented approximately 7.4% of our revenue for the year
ended December 31, 2022, our business would be adversely affected if one or more of our key customers were to have
liquidity problems and be unable to fulfill the terms of their rental agreements with us. Delinquencies and credit losses
generally can be expected to increase during economic slowdowns or recessions. In case of such default in payment
obligations, we may be unable to collect some or all of receivables due to us, in which case some or all outstanding amounts
would need to be written off and we would need to seek alternative sources of funding for our working capital requirements.
If we were to experience any disputes or a significant reduction in or loss of business with one or more customers, or if one
or more customers were to experience difficulty in paying us on a timely basis, our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows could be materially adversely affected.

Furthermore, should a supplier or service provider counterparty become insolvent or otherwise unable to meet its
obligations, we may need to find a replacement to carry out such supply obligations or we may need to fulfill certain service
obligations ourselves, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and
cash flows. Additionally, we are exposed to counterparty risk from our financial investments, derivative financial
instruments and deposits with financial institutions. If a counterparty fails to honor a payment obligation, such a loss will
negatively impact our results of obligations and cash flows. Although we have adopted policies to manage this credit risk
exposure, those policies may not prove effective against the risk of default by, or the insolvency of, one or more
counterparties.

**_We present information relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures in_**
**_this Offering Memorandum; certain of the data used in calculating this information was unaudited or involved certain_**
**_estimates and judgments, and accordingly you should not unduly rely on them._**

This Offering Memorandum includes certain statements and figures relating to Adjusted EBITDA, Pro Forma
Adjusted EBITDA and other non-IFRS measures. These measures may not be comparable to other similarly titled measures
of other companies and are not measurements under IFRS standards or other generally accepted accounting principles. The
Non-IFRS Measures are not measurements of our performance or liquidity under IFRS and should not be considered as
alternatives to operating profit or profit from ordinary operations or any other performance measures derived in accordance
with IFRS or as alternatives to cash flow from operating, investing or financing activities. Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA
and other metrics calculated using Pro Forma Adjusted EBITDA include estimated results of acquired businesses assuming
such acquisitions were made at the beginning of the period presented. We calculated such figures using information and
records available from the acquired businesses, which in certain instances was based on unaudited financial information or
management schedules and therefore required significant assumptions and estimates, may not be up to date or may not be
prepared on the same basis on which we prepare our accounts. While these figures are based upon the latest available
financial information from the acquired business, actual figures may differ. Such figures represent a simple aggregation of
relevant financial information of the Group and certain acquired businesses. Such information does not reflect any
accounting or pro forma adjustments that may be required to present consolidated financial information. This adjustment
is for illustrative purposes only. While we believe these estimates and assumptions to be reasonable, some or all of this
information may prove to be inaccurate or incomplete. As a result, you should not unduly rely on such information in
making an investment in the Notes.

**_Our current financial statements are prepared in accordance with IFRS and are not comparable with our prior financial_**
**_statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP._**

We first prepared annual consolidated financial statements in accordance with IFRS and in accordance with Title
9, Book 2 of the Dutch Civil Code for the year ended December 31, 2022. Until December 31, 2021, we prepared our
consolidated financial statements in accordance with Dutch GAAP. Accordingly, we prepared consolidated financial
statements that comply with IFRS as at and for the year ended December 31, 2022, together with the comparative period


-----

data as at and for the year ended December 31, 2021. In preparing the FY 2022 Financial Statements, our opening statement
of financial position was prepared as at January 1, 2021, the date of our transition to IFRS.

As Dutch GAAP differs in significant respects from IFRS, the adoption of IFRS greatly reduces the comparability
of the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared under IFRS with the FY 2021 Financial Statements and the FY 2020
Financial Statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. In particular, the transition to IFRS resulted in changes to
our accounting policies, methods, estimates, judgments, and disclosures, which affected our reported assets, liabilities,
equity, income, expenses, and cash flows. In this Offering Memorandum, we present our historical financial condition and
results of operations for the year ended December 31, 2021 as derived from the comparative financial information as of
and for the year ended December 31, 2021 included in the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS
and for the year ended December 31, 2020 as derived from the opening statement of financial position as of January 1,
2021 included in Note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements prepared in accordance with IFRS and the Reconciled
Financial Information. See "Presentation of Financial Information." The Reconciled Financial Information for the year
ended December 31, 2020 has been prepared by management to aid in the understanding of our financial information on a
more comparable basis with our financial information for subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS. The
presentation of the Reconciled Financial Information is based on certain management assumptions and estimates, has been
prepared for illustrative purposes only and, because of its nature, the Reconciled Financial Information addresses a
hypothetical situation and, therefore, does not represent and may not give a true picture of our results for the year ended
December 31, 2020 if we had prepared audited financial statements in accordance with IFRS for such period. For example,
the Reconciled Financial Information has not retrospectively applied the IFRS requirements for business combinations as
at January 1, 2020. The Reconciled Financial Information is unaudited, is not fully comparable with our financial
information for subsequent periods and should not be regarded as a substitute for our FY 2020 Financial Statements
prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. Prospective investors are advised to consult their professional advisors for an
understanding of: (i) the differences between Dutch GAAP, IFRS and other systems of generally accepted accounting
principles and how those differences might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum; and
(ii) the impact that future additions to, or amendments of, IFRS may have on the financial information presented in this
Offering Memorandum, our results of operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of prior periods.
For additional information, see "Presentation of Financial Information" and "Management's Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Factors Affecting the Comparability of our Results of Operations—_
_Application of IFRS," "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Certain_
_Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS", and the consolidated financial statements and the accompanying notes_
included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

**Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment**

**_We are subject to stringent environmental and safety requirements, which can be costly to comply with and may subject_**
**_us to liability._**

We store equipment and machinery as well as use and temporarily store fuels and certain chemicals at a variety
of properties in jurisdictions where we have operations, any of which may subject us to stringent environmental
requirements. We also lease or own properties on which industrial activities may have been conducted in the past and there
may be contamination for which we could become liable for clean-up. As such, we may use hazardous materials to clean
and maintain equipment, dispose of solid and hazardous waste and wastewater from equipment washing and store and
dispense petroleum products from underground and aboveground storage tanks located at certain of our locations. In
connection with these activities, we could contaminate soil, air, water and buildings or cause spills, emissions, leakages or
other accidents. We are subject to a variety of environmental regulatory regimes that impose obligations and liability for
the clean-up of properties affected by hazardous substance spills or releases. Such liabilities may be imposed on the parties
generating or disposing of such substances or the operator of the affected property, often without regard to whether the
owner or operator knew of, or was responsible for, the relevant incident. Accordingly, we may become liable, either
contractually or by operation of law, for remediation costs even if a contaminated property is not presently owned or
operated by us or if the contamination was caused by third parties. In addition, we may be liable for the loss of property
value caused by such an incident and prior site assessments or investigations may not have identified all potential instances
of contamination or the full extent thereof. Future events, including changes in existing laws or policies or their
enforcement, or the discovery of currently unknown or undetected incidents, may give rise to additional remediation
liabilities, which may be material. Further, we could also become subject to proceedings where a third party sues us due to
a breach of environmental legislation and be ordered to pay damages or be subject to other sanctions. We have made and
will continue to make capital and other expenditures in order to comply with these environmental and safety compliance
and/or remediation laws and regulations. The requirements of these laws and regulations are complex, change frequently,
and could become more stringent in the future. We may not be in complete compliance with all such requirements at all
times, and we may be subject to potentially significant civil or criminal fines or penalties if we fail to comply. If any of the
risks described above materialize, they may materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.


-----

**_We are subject to risks related to environmental, social and governance matters, including the failure to meet certain of_**
**_our targets._**

We must increasingly meet environmental, social and governance ("ESG") standards and expectations regarding
environmental concerns (such as climate change and sustainability), social concerns (such as diversity, inclusion and human
rights) and corporate governance concerns (such as taking employee relations into account when making business and
investment decisions). Complying with certain ESG standards and expectations, in particular environmental standards, may
pose challenges to our business and could lead to additional costs.

We have set a number of targets with respect to ESG matters. These include ambitious sustainability and
environmental targets relating to our emissions and the sustainability of our fleet, among others. We have also set a number
of diversity and employee satisfaction targets with respect to our business. See "Business—Environmental, Social and
_Governance." Any failure to achieve such targets could damage our reputation, impair our ability to attract and retain key_
personnel and have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

In particular, our emissions targets and targets relating to the development of our green fleet involve significant
costs and are based on numerous assumptions, including, among others, the development or commercial viability of new
technologies and sustainable equipment. Moreover, there is uncertainty with respect to the future supply and pricing of
sustainable equipment, which could impact the level of capital expenditure required to meet our targets. If any of these
assumptions do not materialize, we may be unable to achieve our targets within the set timeframe or without incurring
prohibitive costs, either of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

**_We are exposed to various risks related to legal proceedings or claims._**

We are a party to lawsuits in the normal course of our business. Litigation in general can be expensive, lengthy
and disruptive to normal business operations. Moreover, the results of complex legal proceedings are difficult to predict.
Responding to lawsuits brought against us, or legal actions that we may initiate, can often be expensive and time-consuming
and can divert management's attention from the operation of the business. Unfavorable outcomes from claims or lawsuits
could adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. We could also suffer
reputational harm, incur substantial monetary liability and be required to change our business practices or implement new
systems or procedures which may be costly.

Our business exposes us to claims for personal injury, death or property damage resulting from the use of the
equipment we rent, for injuries caused in motor vehicle accidents in which our delivery and service personnel are involved
and for other employee-related matters. Additionally, we could be subject to potential litigation associated with compliance
with various laws and governmental regulations, such as those relating to employment, health, safety, security and other
regulations under which we operate. Such litigation could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition,
results of operations and cash flows.

**_Our risk management, internal controls and compliance processes may fail to detect, prevent and address the risks we_**
**_face and, as a result, we may be subject to regulatory penalties and reputational damage._**

We operate a decentralized business through hundreds of depots across Europe. Our internal control and
compliance processes may not prevent all future breaches of law, accounting standards or our internal codes of conduct or
to otherwise detect, prevent and address the various risks we face. We may experience instances of fraudulent behavior
and dishonesty by our employees, contractors or other agents. Any failure to comply with applicable laws, regulations and
other standards could lead to fines, legal proceedings, loss of operating licenses and reputational harm, which could in turn
materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations or cash flows.

This risk has increased as a result of our acquisitions and organic growth. In recent years, we have expanded the
size and scope of our operations, including most significantly with the acquisition of Cramo in 2020, and we may continue
to pursue such growth in the future. As we expand the size and scope of our business, there is an increased risk that our
internal controls may not mature at the same pace.

Further, we may be unsuccessful in deploying internal control systems across all of our operating subsidiaries,
and the internal control systems we put in place may be inadequate or ineffective in certain circumstances, particularly if
we are confronted with risks that we have not fully or adequately identified or anticipated. Any such failures of our internal
control systems could adversely impact our ability to monitor local operations and to deploy strategy across our business,
could result in damage to our reputation or otherwise have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition,
results of operations and cash flows.


-----

**_Our business is subject to various legal and regulatory compliance risks, including those involving antitrust, anti-money_**
**_laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations and sanctions._**

We are subject to various legal and regulatory requirements and risks in the countries in which we are
commercially active or have local operations, involving compliance with antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery and
anti-corruption laws, including the U.S. Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and the U.K. Bribery Act, and other regulations and
economic sanctions programs, including those administered by the United Nations, the European Union, the United
Kingdom and the United States. In addition, sanctions imposed by international organizations or individual nations, such
as the sanctions imposed as a result of the military conflict in Ukraine, restrict or prohibit transactions with certain countries,
and with certain companies and individuals identified on lists maintained by the United Nations, the U.S. federal
government, the European Union, various EU member states, the United Kingdom and other local governments. In
particular, the sanctions imposed as a result of the military conflict in Ukraine could impact our ability to sell, and the price
we are able to obtain for, our interest in Fortrent, including requirements to obtain various government approvals for such
a transaction and the transfer of the proceeds thereof. We may be unaware of, or unable to timely anticipate and prepare
for, developments in such laws, regulations and sanctions, and any of our employees, agents, third-party providers or any
other representatives involved in our business may take actions in violation of such laws and regulations, any of which may
subject us to legal or regulatory action by governments or regulators.

Despite the fact that we operate a compliance program, our existing policies, procedures, training, whistleblower
hotline, IT tools, internal controls and risk management in relation to antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anticorruption laws and regulations and sanctions, may not be sufficient in order to prevent or detect inadequate practices,
fraud and violations of law by our employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives. For example, in
the case that any employees, agents, third-party providers or any other representatives with whom we cooperate receive or
grant inappropriate benefits or use corrupt, fraudulent or other unfair business practices, we could be confronted with legal
sanctions, penalties, loss of business as well as harm to our reputation. Due to the increasing complexity, size and
geographical spread of our operations and the extent of our reliance on employees, agents, third-party providers or any
other representatives, it may become more difficult to effectively monitor and control all of our activities, particularly in
markets which are known to be more prone to bribery, corruption and other compliance risks. As a result, our policies,
procedures, internal controls and risk management may not be adequate.

Failure to comply with antitrust, anti-money laundering, anti-bribery or anti-corruption laws and regulations,
sanctions laws and regulations could expose us and our officers, directors and employees to civil and criminal prosecution
and penalties, enforcement actions, the imposition of fines or export or economic sanctions, loss of business or reputational
damage, any of which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash
flows.

**_We are subject to laws and regulations governing labor, compliance with which entails cost and risk, and labor disputes_**
**_could disrupt our operations or lead to higher labor costs._**

Labor laws applicable to our business in the countries where we operate are extensive and compliance therewith
entails significant cost and management attention, particularly so in Austria, Czech Republic, Germany, and Poland. In the
countries in which we operate, labor laws generally provide for strong protection of employees' interests, which may be at
odds with the interests of our business. In addition, many of our employees are members of unions or, based on applicable
regulations, represented by works councils or other bodies. In many cases, we must inform, consult with and request the
consent or opinion of union representatives or work councils in connection with managing, developing or restructuring
certain aspects of our business. These labor laws and consultative procedures could limit our flexibility with respect to
employment policy or economic reorganization and could limit our ability to respond to market changes efficiently. Even
where consultative procedures are not mandatory, important strategic business decisions could be negatively received by
some employees and employees' representative bodies, which could lead to labor actions that could disrupt our business.
We are subject to the risk of labor disputes, which may disrupt our operations. Labor laws applicable to our business in
certain countries, are relatively rigorous. In numerous cases, labor laws provide for the strong protection of employees'
interests. In addition, some of our employees are members of unions or, based on applicable regulations, represented by
work councils or other bodies. Additionally, many of our suppliers and customers have unionized work forces. Strikes,
work-stoppages or work-slowdowns experienced by these suppliers or customers could materially and adversely affect our
business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows. See "Business—Employees."

**_Changes in applicable law and regulations, or our material failure to comply with any of them, can increase our costs,_**
**_expose us to liability and have other negative impacts on our business._**

We are exposed to a wide variety of EU, national and local regulations. See "—Risks related to our Business—
_Our international operations expose us to risks inherent to international business, any of which could materially adversely_
_affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows." These laws and requirements address_

multiple aspects of our operations including, among other things, workplace health and safety, product safety, consumer
rights and labor relations, and such laws and regulations differ from jurisdiction to jurisdiction.

In addition, changes in regulations could impact the ability of rental operators to utilize their equipment in certain
types of projects, affecting the competitive landscape in those projects, as well as in other areas in which the nonconforming equipment may be redeployed. Changes in regulatory requirements, or any material failure to comply with
them, can increase our costs, affect our reputation, limit our business, require significant management attention and
materially adversely affect our business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_Changes in tax laws or challenges to our tax position could adversely affect our results of operations and financial_**
**_condition._**

We are subject to tax laws and regulations in each of the countries where we operate, which may be subject to
change from time to time. Our effective tax rate in any given financial year reflects a variety of factors that may not be
present in succeeding financial years and may be affected by the interpretation of the tax laws of the jurisdictions in which
we operate or changes to such laws. Changes in tax laws and related interpretations and increased enforcement actions and
penalties may alter the environment in which we do business. In addition, certain tax positions that we take are based on
industry practice and external tax advice and/or are based on assumptions that involve a significant degree of judgment. If
challenges to our tax positions (through audits or otherwise) were to be successful, we may be required to pay additional
taxes, penalty charges and interest and may incur costs in defending litigation or reaching a settlement with the relevant
tax authority. Any of the foregoing could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition, results of
operations and cash flows.

We often rely on generally available interpretations of tax laws and regulations in the jurisdictions in which we
operate. These positions may relate to tax compliance (especially in the current international tax context tending towards
enhanced mandatory disclosure obligations), classification of income, treaty relief and withholding tax, franchise, gross
receipts, payroll, property and income tax issues, including tax base. We cannot be certain that the relevant tax authorities
agree with our interpretation of these laws. If our tax positions are challenged by relevant tax authorities, the imposition of
additional taxes could require us to pay taxes that we currently do not collect or pay or increase the costs of our products
or services to track and collect such taxes, which could increase our costs of operations and have a negative effect on our
business, financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.

**_The implementation of Council Directive (EU) 2022/2523 of 14 December 2022 on ensuring a global minimum level of_**
**_taxation for multinational enterprise groups and large-scale domestic groups in the European Union may result in a_**
**_higher tax burden for the Group which could have a negative effect on the Group's solvency and financial condition_**

The Global Anti-Base Erosion Model Rules ("Pillar Two"), an initiative by the OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework,
introduces a minimum level of taxation for multinationals with annual consolidated revenue of €750 million or more in at
least two out of the four fiscal years immediately preceding the tested fiscal year. The aim of Pillar Two is to ensure that
large multinational enterprise groups are subject to a minimum effective tax rate of 15% in each jurisdiction where they
operate.

The Council of the European Union (the EU) formally adopted Council Directive (EU) 2022/2523 (the "Pillar
**Two Directive"). The Pillar Two Directive was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 22 December**
2022. EU member states need to implement the Pillar Two Directive in their national laws by December 31, 2023. On May
31, 2023, the Dutch legislator published a legislative proposal for the implementation of Pillar Two in Dutch law.

The primary mechanism for implementation of Pillar Two will be an income inclusion rule (the "IIR") pursuant
to which a top-up tax is payable by a parent entity of a group if one or more constituent members of the group have been
undertaxed. In the situation that no IIR applies at the ultimate parent entity level, a lower level parent entity may be required
to apply the IIR. A secondary fall back is provided by an undertaxed payment rule (the "UTPR") in case the IIR has not
been applied. The UTPR can be applied by (i) limiting or denying a deduction or (ii) making an adjustment in the form of
an additional tax. In the legislative proposal of May 31, 2023, the Netherlands opted for option (ii) i.e. to make an
adjustment in the form of an additional tax. In addition, and in line with the Pillar Two Directive, the legislative proposal
of May 31, 2023 also includes a qualified domestic minimum top-up tax (the "QDMTT"). A jurisdiction that incorporates
the QDMTT becomes the first in line to levy any top-up tax from entities located in its jurisdiction. It must compute profits
and calculate any top-up tax due in the same way as the Pillar Two rules. Without a QDMTT, another jurisdiction as
determined by the Pillar Two rules would be entitled to levy the top-up tax.

The implementation of the Pillar Two Directive could result in a higher tax burden for the Group which could
have a negative effect on the Group's solvency and financial condition.
