**Overview**

We are a leading rental equipment specialist in Europe. We believe we are the second largest equipment rental
company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, with strong market positions across our main markets, including the largest
market share in each of the Netherlands, Belgium and Sweden and the second largest market share in each of Germany and
Finland, in each case in terms of revenue in 2022. Our family-owned business started out of four garage boxes in the 1970s,
and, under five decades later, has expanded into an industry leader with an extensive network of 759 depots in 18 European
countries and a fleet of approximately 860,000 rental units as at June 30, 2023. In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023,
we generated €1,524.9 million in revenue and €540.2 million in Adjusted EBITDA.

We serve customers in a variety of end-markets from civil engineering, industrial, construction and infrastructure
to events and warehousing. Our core product offering includes general and specialist rental equipment alongside
complementary products and services, enabling us to be a one-stop-shop for our customer base of both corporate clients
(business-to-business) and individuals including craftsmen and retail clients (business-to-consumer). Our generalist
division is mainly focused on the less cyclical 'fit-out, maintain and operate' market segments which use lighter equipment,
while our specialist division is tailored to reach niche markets, such as site preparation, sanitation and access control.

With approximately 860,000 rental items, with a purchase value of €2.8 billion as of June 30, 2023, we offer our
customers access to one of the largest, widest, highest quality, and latest ranges of rental equipment and tools in Europe,
for use in the fields of civil engineering (such as excavators, landscaping tools and dumpers), transport and handling (such
as forklifts, cranes and trailers), climate control (such as heating and cooling systems, mobile boilers and air purifiers), and
construction (such as construction site and installation products), among others. In addition to our vast range of tools and
equipment available in our general depots, we provide a wide range of specialist products to niche markets primarily outside
the construction industry, which we believe differentiates us from our competition and contributes to our strong brand
recognition and greater diversification in terms of end-markets and product offering. Our specialist products range from
HVAC systems and hoisting and lifting machines to mobile LED screens, temporary housing solutions, portable kitchens
and heavy duty pumps. In parallel, we offer "do-it-yourself" ("DIY") shop-in-shops across Europe, in partnership with DIY
retailers where retail clients get access to primarily smaller equipment rental, which we believe further renders our business
less cyclical than the traditional equipment rental business. Our corresponding service lines are geared towards further
simplifying our customers' complex projects and include equipment service and maintenance, fuel management, training
courses, project management and emergency assistance.

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain information for the following four geographic regions:

    - **_The Netherlands, which generated €362.9 million in revenue (representing 23.8% of our revenue) in the_**
twelve months ended June 30, 2023;

    - **_Central Europe, consisting of Belgium, Germany, Austria, Hungary, Switzerland, Luxembourg, Poland,_**
the Czech Republic and Slovakia, which generated €538.9 million in revenue (representing 35.3% of our
revenue) in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023;

    - **_Northern Europe, consisting of Sweden, Norway, Finland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, which_**

    - **_Other Countries, consisting of Italy and the United Kingdom, which generated €46.4 million in revenue_**

_Financial Information—Operating Segments."_


-----

We operate under two main brands: Boels Rental and Cramo. Boels Rental, the original brand of the Boels Group,
is active in 12 countries in Central and Western Europe and we believe holds the strongest brand recognition across our
portfolio. Cramo is active in the Nordic and the Baltic states, having been an independent leading rental company in Europe
since 1953 before we acquired it in 2020.

We operate a hub-and-spoke depot network, consisting of 681 general rental product depots and 78 specialist
rental product depots as of June 30, 2023. We believe the decentralized structure of our network enables us to provide our
products and services to our customers more conveniently and efficiently, while also supplying us with a diversified and
local customer reach. In countries where we have an extensive depot network, such as the Netherlands and Germany, each
depot is connected to a central hub location. In countries with larger markets, we have several hubs. Our depots generally
stock smaller and more commonly used equipment, while the larger and less commonly used equipment is stored at our
hubs, from where they can be easily shipped directly to a customer or local depot as needed. We believe this structure
allows us to make more efficient use of our fleet and minimize transport movements.

Through a combination of organic growth and strategic acquisitions, we have expanded significantly over the past
decade, both in terms of geographical reach and product offering. Since Pierre Boels Jr. became the CEO of Boels in 1996,
we have executed a growth strategy based on product portfolio diversification and greenfield openings (including through
international expansion), as well as through strategic bolt-on acquisitions executed to enter specific geographic areas (such
as Germany, the UK and the Nordics) or specialist markets (such as industrial rental and traffic service). In 2020, we
acquired Cramo, which positioned us as one of the largest equipment rental companies in Europe and complemented our
geographic presence with an expansion into the Nordics and a further extension of our Central European offering. In
addition, our 2022 acquisition of Eekels Pompen allowed us to expand our specialist product line by adding a high-quality
offering of pump rentals to our customers with niche needs.

The sharing economy is at the very heart of our business, and we believe that long-term growth prospects for the
equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, driven by increased consumer preferences for rental instead of
ownership. From our perspective, renting provides our customers with optimal availability, accessibility, and capital
deployment, enabling them to reduce the amount of capital required for their operations, and, in turn, increase their capacity
to deploy it for other investments. As such, our rental concept aims to help customers and their end-consumers meet their
targets in terms of costs, efficiency, quality and sustainability. We also believe that rental, compared to ownership, can
contribute positively to the environment. Therefore, alongside the benefits that we strive to offer our customers, we also
invest in products and solutions that align with our commitment to advancing sustainability in our and our customers'
industries.

**Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations**

Our results of operations are primarily affected by factors that impact the equipment rental industry generally,
particularly cyclicality and economic conditions affecting the civil engineering, industry, construction and infrastructure
sectors, and our management of capital expenditures in response to changes in the cycle. Our results of operations are also
affected by the expansion of our rental network through acquisitions and the opening and closing of depots. Our results of
operations can also be impacted by seasonality and currency fluctuations in our principal markets. These factors are
described in greater detail below. For trends affecting our business and the markets in which we operate, see also "Risk
_Factors," "Industry Overview" and "Business."_

**_Economic Conditions_**

Demand for our products is dependent on the industries in which our customers operate, the general economy and
other factors. Many of the markets in which our customers operate are cyclical, with activity levels that tend to increase
during periods of economic growth and decline during economic downturns. Demand for our products is correlated to
conditions in these industries and in the general economy, including credit markets.

Conditions in the markets in which our customers operate have an impact on both the utilization rate of our
equipment and on prices. As demand increases, so do utilization rates, and we can then, subject to existing agreements with
customers, choose to allocate equipment to customers who are willing to pay higher prices. When demand decreases, so
do utilization rates, and we may reduce prices to preserve utilization levels. Demand can be affected by general economic
trends and cycles that can have an impact (positive or negative) over a longer period and by short-term factors, such as
seasonality, that affect the utilization rates and prices for a brief period. See "—Seasonality" below. In the past, we have
managed the impact of medium and long-term trends by optimizing our rental fleet utilization rate, developing specialist
activities focused on non-construction-related niche markets (such as the DIY market and the market for pumping
equipment), diversifying our customer base by investing in a broad product range aimed at non-construction-related
customers and focusing on the less cyclical phases of construction such as the fit-out, maintain and operation phases. We
seek to further manage such trends through adjustment of our investments in new equipment, increases or decreases in
sales of our equipment and the management of our depot network.

During the year ended December 31, 2020, our business operations were affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
Results differed by country depending on the severity of the government restrictions imposed and the severity of the


-----

pandemic. The decrease in our level of activity, in line with the decrease in market activity, was most notable in Italy,
Austria, Belgium and the United Kingdom, where strict lockdown measures were imposed. In particular, as the entire
events industry came to a halt, demand from the events end market sharply contracted. Conversely, the COVID-19
pandemic had a positive impact on certain aspects of our business, such as unit rentals and our DIY business. We deployed
a number of measures to mitigate the effects of the pandemic on the Group, including lowering the planned levels of capital
expenditure and introducing a significant cost savings program. See also "—Operating Expenses" below. After a decrease
in demand in 2020 related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the equipment rental market rebounded in line with the construction
market, which benefitted from household savings, low interest rates and a relaunch of governmental construction projects.
As a result of the measures we implemented in response to the pandemic and the recovery in demand that followed, we
were able to generate positive Reported EBITDA of €432.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 (based on the
Reconciled Financial Information), and we increased our sales across all of our geographic regions in the year ended
December 31, 2021, most notably in Northern Europe, driven by general economic growth and several large projects.

Since February 2022, the Russian invasion of Ukraine has destabilized the financial and commodity markets and
resulted in an uncertain macroeconomic situation in Europe, causing inflation throughout the economy, to which central
banks have responded with rises in interest rates, and volatile energy prices. Although we have continued to experience
growth in revenue and Reported EBITDA, these macroeconomic factors could have an adverse effect on the demand for
rental services and, paired with other economic developments, impact our operating expenses and the cost of new
equipment we purchase for our rental fleet. In addition, we have historically had a shareholding in Fortrent, a 50% owned
joint venture with Ramirent Oyj with operations in Russia, which was accounted for in our consolidated financial statements
under the equity method. Considering the level of uncertainty due to the geopolitical situation resulting from the war in
Ukraine and the high volatility of the Russian ruble, we fully impaired our investment in Fortrent in the year ended
December 31, 2022, which included the write-down of the full amount of the carrying value of our investment in Fortrent
amounting to €10.9 million, the depreciation of certain receivables amounting to €0.9 million and the reversal of the net
result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €2.6 million for the period. In the six months ended June 30, 2023, we reversed
the net result of Fortrent amounting to a gain of €1.1 million for the period. In June 2022, we, together with our joint
venture partner, decided to sell Fortrent. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, our interest in Fortrent continues to
be held for sale.

Despite the uncertain macroeconomic environment in the year ended December 31, 2022, we increased our
revenue and Reported EBITDA by 11.6% and 10.8%, respectively, compared to the year ended December 31, 2021,
demonstrating the resilience of our business model. In this period, each of our geographic regions experienced strong
performance, with revenue generated by the Netherlands, Central Europe, Northern Europe and Other Countries (primarily
Italy and the United Kingdom) regions increasing by 17.8%, 9.9%, 9.8% and 8.7%, respectively, compared to the prior
year. In addition, while the inflationary environment resulted in an increase in our operating expenses during the year,
particularly repair and maintenance expenses, transportation expenses and housing expenses, we were able to preserve our
margins through our ability to increase prices and generate operational efficiencies.

Acquisitions impact our financial position and results of operations in a variety of ways. We incur costs related to

and typically aim to pay EBITDA multiples of less than 4.5x for bolt-on acquisitions. Acquisitions may result in the

business. Between January 1, 2021 and June 30, 2023, after the integration of Cramo Central Europe, we estimate that
more than 90% of our revenue growth has been organic.

**_Capital Expenditures, Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals_**

The management of our level of capital expenditure by increasing or decreasing the amount of investment in our
fleet is an important factor in our results of operations and cash flow. Decisions about investment in new equipment are
based on the condition and remaining useful life of our existing equipment as well as on our views of future demand,
legislative developments and the industry transition towards higher sustainability standards. During growth cycles, we may
decide to invest in our fleet by replacing aging equipment or equipment at the end of its useful economic life and by
expanding the total size of the fleet, which in turn also reduces the average age of the fleet. In downturns we have the ability
to limit capital expenditures to the replacement equipment at the end of its useful economic life and let the average age of
the fleet slowly increase in order to conserve cash. In the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, our Capital Expenditure
(excluding acquisitions) amounted to €356.0 million and €533.4 million, respectively. In the year ended December 31,
2020, our Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) amounted to €206.5 million on a Dutch GAAP basis, with no
adjustments to this figure in the Reconciled Financial Information. In addition, we benefit from a well-invested fleet of
rental equipment with an average fleet age significantly below the average useful life, which enables us to control our
maintenance capital expenditure levels. As a proxy, we target annual maintenance capital expenditure of approximately
10% of our total fleet purchase value, less income generated from the sale of used equipment. Our Capital Expenditure
(excluding acquisitions) during the period under review related primarily to growth in activity, greenfield depot openings
and the development of a diversified, sustainable fleet in order to position us to capitalize on growth opportunities.

In the year ended December 31, 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, investments in our fleet increased
the number of serialized rental items by approximately 6% and 3%, respectively, reflecting a broadening of our existing
assortment and our continued investment in the Eco-label fleet. These investments resulted in a decrease in the weighted
average fleet age from 55 months in 2021, to 54 months in 2022 and 53 months as of June 30, 2023.

We determine the allocation of investments in our rental fleet by the type of equipment and the requirements of
our business units. We divide our equipment into several subgroups, which enables us to analyze the best strategic
deployment, combined with the best possible use for customers, the lowest downtime and the most efficient economies of
scale. As of June 30, 2023, our rental units were comprised of approximately 39% tools, 27% energy and climate, 13%
material handling, 11% site huts and site preparation, 5% earthmoving and 4% access equipment.

We continue to invest in our fleet to remain on top of market developments and play a leading role in the energy
transition within the equipment rental sector, with a substantial amount of our planned capital expenditure to be invested
in our Eco-label and zero-emission fleet. Of our total energy powered fleet, approximately 81% is electric as of June 30,
2023 and we aim to increase this percentage to 85% by 2025. Our aim is to be the frontrunner in investing in innovative
solutions to increase the sustainability of our fleet.

In addition, we generate revenue from the sale of assets in our fleet. In a typical year, we target selling assets in
our fleet with a resale value of between €50 million and €60 million and realizing a profit margin compared to book value
of between 40% and 50% depending on market conditions. In the year ended December 31, 2022, we generated 3.4% of
our revenue from the sale of assets in our fleet. We sell assets in our fleet when we believe that these assets have reached
the end of their useful life because they have become obsolete or when the cost of maintaining them in proper condition
for customer use is too high. We may also sell assets in our fleet before the end of their useful life if we believe a decline
in demand in a given market is likely to last for a significant period of time or if otherwise economical to do so. For instance,
in 2022, the market for used equipment showed a high level of volatility and, as a result, we decided to resell certain
categories of equipment and purchase new and more sustainable substitute equipment.

**_Operating Expenses_**

Our business, like that of all equipment rental groups, is capital-intensive with a predominantly fixed cost structure
that principally relates to the depreciation of our equipment fleet, operating expenses (such as personnel charges) that are


-----

relatively fixed for short or long periods of time, and to a lesser extent, real estate lease expenses. Some of our operating
expenses, such as depreciation of right-of-use assets (which are linked to real estate lease payments) and personnel charges
in certain countries, may be linked to indices, including consumer price indices, which may increase due to inflation.

The management of our costs is an important factor in our results of operations and cash flows. With our
centralized fleet ownership model, we seek to deploy our fleet efficiently across our network to respond to actual or
anticipated increases and decreases in demand rather than renting additional equipment from third parties to then rent it out
to our customers or duplicating investments in the same piece of equipment in different geographies, which could eventually
lead to over-capacity. We also monitor our costs and margins on a regular basis. For example, when faced with more
challenging market conditions in 2020 as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, we implemented a significant cost savings
program, which included cutting certain fixed costs, such as staff costs through utilizing temporary contracts to increase
the flexibility of our workforce during the period, as well as rationalizing our investment program on our fleet to focus on
added value. In addition, we use temporary staffing from local employment agencies and contractor agencies where
additional resources are needed for specific projects or to fill a vacant position in the short term, which enables us to
maintain flexibility in our staff costs. For example, from March 2020, following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic,
we reduced our usage of temporary staff to manage our costs. Following the recovery in market activity in 2021, we
increased our usage of temporary staff, which, together with higher hourly rates reflecting labor market shortages and the
inflationary environment, resulted in an increase in our temporary staffing costs. This increase is reflected in our employee
benefits expense in our statement of profit or loss.

**_Seasonality_**

Our operations experience a degree of seasonality in the first quarter of each year, driven principally by climatic
conditions in our different regions of operations. For example, in certain regions in which we operate, demand in the
construction and civil engineering markets tends to decrease in winter and during extended periods of inclement weather
while increasing in the summer and during extended periods of mild weather. However, the seasonality impact on our
results of operations is relatively small given regional variations in the response to working practices in connection with
weather, as some regions experience little to no change in operational activity despite weather variations.

**_Currency Fluctuations_**

The majority of our revenue (66.6% for the year ended December 31, 2022), expenses and obligations are
denominated in euro. However, our results of operations are affected by changes in foreign exchange rates, as we generate
revenue and incur expenses in a variety of currencies other than our reporting currency, the euro, primarily the Swedish
krona, the Norwegian krone, the Danish krone, the British pound, the Polish zloty, Swiss franc and the Czech koruna. We
also have net investments in foreign subsidiaries that are exposed to currency translation risk. We use forward exchange
contracts to hedge some of our currency risks, mainly related to our cash flows in Sweden, Norway, the United Kingdom,
Poland and the Czech Republic. However, we cannot eliminate all of our currency risks, and any significant or prolonged
adverse movements in exchange rates could have a negative impact on our profitability, cash flows and financial position.
As of June 30, 2023 and December 31, 2022, we had outstanding forward exchange contracts with a nominal value of
€383.0 million and €250.3 million, respectively, and a positive market value of €2.5 million and €2.4 million, respectively.
The effectiveness of our hedging strategy depends on various factors, such as the accuracy of our forecasts, the availability
and cost of hedging instruments, and the volatility of the currency markets. We monitor our currency exposure and hedge
ratios on a regular basis and adjust our hedging activities as appropriate.

**_Interest Rate Fluctuations_**

Our financial expenses are affected by the movement of interest rates, particularly EURIBOR, which is the
reference rate for most of our floating rate borrowings. Our policy is to hedge a portion of our interest rate risk by entering
into interest rate swaps, which effectively convert some of our floating rate liabilities into fixed rate liabilities. However,
we are not fully hedged and we remain exposed to changes in interest rates on our unhedged borrowings and on the fair
value of our interest rate swaps. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 69% of the outstanding
principal amount of our Existing Term Loan B was hedged through February 2028 with €1,000 million in notional amount
of interest rate swaps. Pursuant to such interest rate swaps, the fixed interest rate at which EURIBOR has been swapped is
0.44% until February 2026, 2.84% between February 2026 and February 2027, and 2.68% between February 2027 and
February 2028. See also "—Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks—Market Risks—Interest rate
_risk."_

In the year ended December 31, 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, we experienced an increase in
financial expenses due to the rise in EURIBOR. This resulted in higher interest payments on our unhedged floating rate
borrowings. We monitor the interest rate environment and the effectiveness of our hedging strategy on a regular basis and
may adjust our hedging position as appropriate to achieve our desired risk profile. We also consider the availability and


-----

cost of alternative sources of financing and the maturity profile of our debt portfolio to optimize our capital structure and
liquidity position.

The historical financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum is affected by the acquisition of
Cramo in 2020, which may make it more difficult for investors to evaluate the historical performance of our business.

On November 11, 2019, we entered into a combination agreement with Cramo, pursuant to which we made a
voluntary recommended public cash tender offer to purchase the outstanding shares in Cramo. Pursuant to the tender offer,
on February 5, 2020, we acquired approximately 93.04% of the issued and outstanding shares in Cramo. For practical
reasons, we consolidated Cramo in our financial statements as of February 1, 2020. Pursuant to a subsequent redemption
process and squeeze-out procedure, we acquired the remaining outstanding shares in Cramo on June 3, 2020.

Our audited consolidated financial statements and the financial information presented in this Offering
Memorandum as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 reflect the results of Cramo for the period from February 1,
2020 to December 31, 2020 only. Cramo contributed €514 million and €125 million to our revenue and Reported EBITDA
between February 1, 2020 and December 31, 2020, respectively, on a Dutch GAAP basis. Our audited consolidated
financial statements and the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum as of and for the year ended
December 31, 2020 do not include the results of Cramo for the period from January 1, 2020 to January 31, 2020. As a
result, the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum for the year ended December 31, 2020 is not fully
comparable to the financial information presented for subsequent periods.

The acquisition of Cramo had a significant impact on our results for the year ended December 31, 2020 due to the
costs associated with the acquisition and financing of Cramo and several one-off costs related to restructuring measures
and the integration of the Cramo business. Capital expenditure related to the acquisition of Cramo comprised 74% of our
Gross Capital Expenditure in the year ended December 31, 2020. The acquisition of Cramo was financed by a senior credit
facility (which was subsequently refinanced), resulting in an increase in our net interest bearing liabilities and an increase
in our interest expense.

**Explanation of Key Line Items from the Statement of Profit or Loss**

The following is a summary description of certain line items from our statement of profit or loss presented in
IFRS. For more information see "—Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates" and the notes to our consolidated audited
financial statements.

_Revenue_ is comprised of revenue from equipment rental, which reflects the fees paid by customers to rent
equipment, and revenue from sales of goods and other services, which reflects the sale of rental equipment at the end of its
useful economic life and the sale of certain items associated with the use of rental equipment and fees paid by customers
for additional services relating to equipment rental. In the six months ended June 30, 2023 and in the year ended December


-----

31, 2022, revenue from equipment rental represented 69% and 71% of our total revenue, respectively, and revenue from
sales of goods and other services represented 31% and 29% of our total revenue, respectively.

_Materials and services principally includes cost of rental and rental-sharing, cost of goods sold, repair and_
maintenance cost, logistics cost, property cost, office cost, marketing and sales cost and other external costs

_Employee benefits expense relates primarily to the salaries, social security charges, pension charges and other_
personnel costs for our employees.

_Depreciation and amortization expense principally includes depreciation of property, plant and equipment (fleet_
and non-fleet). Depreciation and amortization also includes depreciation of intangible assets (trademarks and customer
relationships). Under IFRS 16, as a lessee, we account for right-of-use assets associated with leases and recognize
amortization in respect thereof on a straight-line basis over the lease term.

_Net impairment losses on financial assets includes losses on bad debts, net of change in provisions on current_
assets.

_Other operating expenses represents the impairment of investments in joint ventures, which in the year ended_
December 31, 2022 reflected our impairment of our investment in Fortrent.

_Financial income primarily includes interest income on cash balances._

_Financial expense comprises interest charges on bank loans and hedging expenses. It also includes changes in the_
fair value of derivatives instruments and the interest cost related to the lease liability generated by the application of the
IFRS 16 standard.

_Income tax expense consists of current and deferred taxes calculated in accordance with the relevant tax laws in_
force in the jurisdictions in which we operate. As of June 30, 2023, the statutory corporate tax rate in the Netherlands was
25.8%. We are also subject to tax rates in the other countries in which we operate.

_Share of profit of joint venture represents results from our investments in associates and joint ventures, which are_
accounted for under the equity method, except when the investment is classified as held for sale, in which case it is
accounted for in accordance with IFRS 5.

**_Six months ended June 30, 2023 (IFRS) compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022 (IFRS)_**

_Revenue_

Our revenue increased by 7.8% to €758.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023, compared to €703.0
million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to strong performance across all of our key geographic
markets, as discussed further below. Additionally, we experienced organic growth as a result of the expansion of our depot
network by six new locations, bringing the total to 759 as of June 30, 2023. Growth from acquisitions in the period included
the acquisitions of BAS Maskinutleie, KraftX and Illumin8 Lights as well as the acquisition of the assets of Hyresbutiken


-----

and Safelift, which, together, added 20 depots to our network. Out of the total revenue increase of 7.8% during the period,
we estimate that approximately 6.7% of the total was derived from organic growth.

Revenue generated by the Netherlands region increased by 14.1% to €183.5 million in the six months ended June
30, 2023, from €160.8 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to significant growth in both our
specialist and general rental product portfolios and the increasing demand in the industrial end market.

Revenue generated by the Central Europe region increased by 10.0% to €269.5 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2023, from €244.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to strong performance in the
general rental product portfolio in Germany and the Czech Republic, with modest growth in Belgium, Austria and
Luxembourg.

Revenue generated by the Northern Europe region increased by 2.7% to €281.8 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2023, from €274.3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to organic growth in most
countries within the region as well as the acquisitions of BAS Maskinutleie in Norway and Hyresbutiken and KraftX in
Sweden, partially offset by the unfavorable impact of the exchange rate of each of the Swedish krona and the Norwegian
krone against the euro.

Revenue generated by the Other Countries region slightly increased by 1.3% to €23.3 million in the six months
ended June 30, 2023, from €23.0 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to organic growth, as well
as the acquisition of Illumin8 Lights in the United Kingdom, partially offset by the unfavorable impact of the exchange
rate of the British pound against the euro.

_Operating Expenses_

Materials and Services

Materials and services expenses increased by 4.0% to €269.4 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023,
compared to €259.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the increase in
logistics costs, mainly attributable to the sales growth during the period, as well as higher prices for fuel, parts and services.

Employee Benefits Expense

Employee benefits expense increased by 12.1% to €222.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023,
compared to €198.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to an increase in the
average number of employees to 7,058 full time equivalents for the six months ended June 30, 2023, from 6,692 full time
equivalents for the six months ended June 30, 2022, as well as growth in wages and salaries which were increased as a
result of the inflationary environment over the period. In addition, we incurred higher expenses for temporary staff in the
six months ended June 30, 2023 due to an increase in the number of temporary staff and higher hourly rates for such
temporary staff.

Depreciation and Amortization Expense

Depreciation and amortization expense increased by 6.4% to €171.0 million in the six months ended June 30,
2023, compared to €160.7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to the significant increase of capital
expenditures during the year ended December 31, 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, reflecting investments in
our rental fleet and acquisitions. See "—Capital Expenditures" below.

Net Impairment Losses on Financial Assets

Net impairment losses on financial assets decreased by 21.4% to €1.1 million in the six months ended June 30,
2023, compared to €1.4 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to improved aging of outstanding
receivables, which reduced loss allowances of trade and other receivables.

_Financial Income and Expense_

Our net financial expense increased significantly from a net expense of €30.2 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2022 to a net expense of €43.3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023, primarily due to an increase in
interest expense in the six months ended June 30, 2023 as a result of an increase in EURIBOR, which impacted the rate at
which interest accrued on our unhedged floating-rate indebtedness, and an increase in our gross indebtedness over the
period. We benefitted from the effectiveness of our interest rate hedging policy, which partially mitigated the impact of the
increase in EURIBOR over the period.


-----

_Income Tax Expense_

Our income tax expense increased to €14.4 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023, compared to €5.8
million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to the recognition of deferred tax assets for carry forward
losses from previous years in Germany and Finland in 2022, which we partially allocated to the six months ended June 30,
2022.

_Profit for the period_

As a result of the factors discussed above, we recorded a profit of €39.7 million in the six months ended June 30,
2023, a decrease of 21.7%, compared to a profit of €50.7 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022.

**_Year ended December 31, 2022 (IFRS) compared to year ended December 31, 2021 (IFRS)_**

_Revenue_

Our revenue increased by 11.6% to €1,469.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €1,317.4
million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to strong performance across all of our key markets and an
increase in prices, as discussed further below. The vast majority of our revenue growth in 2022 was organic as a result of
the expansion of our depot network by 19 new locations, bringing the total to 743 as of December 31, 2022. Growth from
acquisitions in the period was limited to the acquisition of Eekels Pompen in the year ended December 31, 2022, which
also added three depots to our network.

Revenue generated by the Netherlands region increased by 17.8% to €340.2 million in the year ended December
31, 2022, from €288.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to growth in sales from our general
rental activities, strong growth in sales from specialist rental activities (including from the acquisition of Eekels Pompen),
as well as an increase in sales to the industrial end market.

Revenue generated by the Central Europe region increased by 9.9% to €514.3 million in the year ended December
31, 2022, from €467.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to sales growth across all countries
within the region, with notable growth in Eastern European markets, while Belgium and Luxembourg showed stable
performance under tougher economic circumstances during the year.

Revenue generated by the Northern Europe region increased by 9.8% to €569.3 million in the year ended
December 31, 2022, from €518.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to strong performance and
growth in sales across all countries in the region, supported by investment in our fleet in both years. Sweden and Finland,
our two largest markets within the region, experienced notable growth, with Sweden particularly supported by large
industrial projects. Despite the uncertainty and geopolitical developments in the region, the Baltic countries showed the
strongest growth in the Northern Europe region. In addition, Norway experienced significant growth in sales compared to
the prior year, despite a stronger competitive environment.

Revenue generated by the Other Countries region increased by 8.7% to €46.1 million in the year ended December
31, 2022, from €42.4 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This was driven by strong economic conditions in the
construction industry in the United Kingdom and Italy, respectively, in 2022, following the market recovery in 2021 after
the COVID-19 pandemic.

_Operating Expenses_

Materials and Services

Materials and services expenses increased by 12.1%, in line with the increase in sales during the year, to €535.5
million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €477.7 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This
increase was primarily due to the increase in logistics costs, mainly attributed to the sales growth during the year, as well
as higher prices for fuel, parts and services and certain rental related services.

Employee Benefits Expense

Employee benefits expense increased by 12.3%, in line with the increase in sales during the year, to €410.5 million
in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €365.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase
was primarily due to an increase in the average number of employees to 6,515 full time equivalents for the year ended
December 31, 2022, from 6,329 full time equivalents for the year ended December 31, 2021, to support the growth of our
business and annual salary increases driven by inflation during the year.


-----

Depreciation and Amortization Expense

Depreciation and amortization expense increased by 7.7% to €326.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022,
compared to €303.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the significant increase of capital
expenditures in tangible and intangible assets in the year ended December 31, 2022, which resulted in increased
depreciation of property, plant and equipment. See "—Capital Expenditures" below.

Net Impairment Losses on Financial Assets

Net impairment losses on financial assets increased by 15.6% to €3.7 million in the year ended December 31,
2022, compared to €3.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to growth in activities and sales,
resulting in an increase in expected credit losses.

Other Operating Expenses

We recognized other operating expenses of €11.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to nil
in the year ended December 31, 2021, reflecting the write-down of our investment in Fortrent. See "—Key Factors Affecting
_Results of Operations—Economic Conditions" for additional information._

_Financial Income and Expense_

Our net financial expense increased from a net expense of €70.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021 to
a net expense of €71.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, primarily due to an increase in interest expense in
2022 as a result of an increase in EURIBOR, which impacted the rate at which interest accrued on our floating-rate
indebtedness, and an increase in our gross indebtedness compared to 2021. This increase was partially offset by the
repricing of our Existing Term Loan B in June 2021, which resulted in lower interest rate margins in the second half of
2021. We also benefitted from the effectiveness of our interest rate hedging policy, which partially mitigated the impact of
the increase in EURIBOR over the period.

_Income Tax Expense_

Our income tax expense decreased by 32.4% to €14.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to
€21.0 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to the recognition of deferred tax assets previously not
recognized for carry forward losses from previous years in Germany and Finland in the year ended December 31, 2022,
partially offset by an increase in current tax expenses for the year ended December 31, 2022.

_Share of Profit of Joint Venture_

Our share of profit of joint venture was nil in the year ended December 31, 2022, compared to €1.0 million in the
year ended December 31, 2021, reflecting our decision to classify our investment in the Fortrent joint venture as assets
held for sale for the year ended December 31, 2022. See "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Economic
_Conditions" for additional information._

_Profit for the year_

As a result of the factors discussed above, we recorded a profit of €100.9 million in the year ended December 31,
2022, an increase of 25.3% compared to a profit of €80.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021.

31, 2021, from €439.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to a recovery of activity in certain
Eastern European markets in 2021, which had been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020, and the full-year

Revenue generated by the Northern Europe region increased by 21.3% to €518.4 million in the year ended
December 31, 2021, from €427.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to an increase in demand for

Revenue generated by the Other Countries region increased by 23.6% to €42.4 million in the year ended December

which had been curtailed from March 2020 following the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Depreciation and Amortization Expense

Depreciation and amortization expense increased by 1.5% to €303.3 million in the year ended December 31, 2021,
compared to €298.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020, primarily due to the full-year effect of the Cramo
acquisition in 2021 (compared to 11 months in 2020) and increased level of investment activities in the course of 2021.

Net Impairment Losses on Financial Assets

Net impairment losses on financial assets decreased by 44% to €3.2 million in the year ended December 31, 2021,
compared to €5.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to provisions recognized
in 2020 relating to outstanding receivables of certain Cramo entities acquired in 2020, as well as the improved economic

a net expense of €70.5 million in the year ended December 31, 2021, primarily due to certain fees and expenses related to

**Liquidity and Capital Resources**

Our primary sources of cash are cash flows from operating activities and borrowings under our debt facilities,
including the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and our Trade Receivables Purchase Program, and we may from time to
time issue debt securities. Our principal uses of cash have been, and we expect will continue to be, operating expenses,
capital expenditures, working capital requirements, acquisitions and debt service payments. As of June 30, 2023, our cash
and cash equivalents amounted to €1.1 million.

We currently have, and following the completion of the Transactions, will continue to have, substantial
indebtedness. See "Description of Certain Financing Arrangements." As adjusted for the Transactions, as of June 30, 2023,
we would have had outstanding €1,906.6 million of total net debt. See "Capitalization." Our indebtedness levels may have
important negative consequences for noteholders. See "Risk Factors." There are also limitations on our ability to obtain
additional debt financing. See "Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Indebtedness." Further, any
additional indebtedness that we do incur could reduce the amount of our cash flow available to make payments on our then
existing indebtedness, including under the Notes offered hereby.

Our ability to make principal or interest payments when due on our indebtedness, including our obligations under
the Notes, and to fund our ongoing operations, will depend on our future performance and our ability to generate cash,
which, to a certain extent, is subject to general economic, financial, industry, regulatory and other factors, as well as other
factors discussed in "Risk Factors," many of which are beyond our control.

We believe that, based on our current level of operations, our cash on hand, cash flows from operating activities
and the availability of borrowings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility and the Trade Receivables Purchase
Program will be sufficient to fund our operating expenses, capital expenditures and debt service payments for at least the
next twelve months.

**_Six months ended June 30, 2023 (IFRS) compared to the six months ended June 30, 2022 (IFRS)_**

_Net cash from operating activities_

Net cash from operating activities decreased by 43.8% to €128.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023,
compared to €228.1 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to a significant increase in changes in
working capital, from an impact of negative €3.6 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022 to an impact of negative
€115.8 million for the six months ended June 30, 2023. This increase was primarily due to a large delivery of new fleet in
the fourth quarter of 2022, for which payment was made in the six months ended June 30, 2023.

_Net cash used in investing activities_

Net cash used in investing activities increased by 26.8% to €285.6 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023,
compared to €225.3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to an increase in investments in our rental
fleet and other assets and acquisitions. Gross Capital Expenditure increased to €289.1 million for the six months ended
June 30, 2023, from €225.3 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, of which cash used for acquisitions amounted
to €52.7 million and €16.6 million, respectively.

_Net cash (used in)/from financing activities_

Net cash (used in)/from financing activities amounted to an inflow of €141.5 million in the six months ended June
30, 2023, compared to an outflow of €29.9 million in the six months ended June 30, 2022, primarily due to an increase in
the use of the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, of which €131.6 million was drawn as of June 30, 2023, in combination
with the use of the Trade Receivables Purchase Program, established in June 2023, in an amount of €48.1 million. This
was partially offset by a €13.0 million distribution of dividends to the Parent in March 2023, of which €6.8 million was
paid in cash and the remainder was settled with outstanding receivables from related parties.

**Capital Expenditures**

Our capital expenditures consist principally of investments in fixed assets (in particular, our equipment fleet). We
determine and allocate our budget for capital expenditures on an annual basis and update it on a regular basis throughout
the year based on market developments. Decisions about investment in new equipment are based on the condition and
remaining useful life of our existing equipment as well as on our views of future demand, legislative developments and the


-----

industry transition towards higher sustainability standards. During growth cycles, we may decide to invest in our fleet by
replacing aging equipment or equipment at the end of its useful economic life and by expanding the total size of the fleet,
while in downturns, we have the ability to limit capital expenditures to the replacement of equipment at the end of its useful
economic life in order to conserve cash. See also "—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures,
_Fleet Age and Equipment Disposals."_

We define Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) as purchases of property, plant and equipment plus
purchases of intangible assets shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows and Gross Capital Expenditure as Capital
Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) plus acquisitions shown on our consolidated statement of cash flows. However, other
companies may present Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure differently than we
do. We present Capital Expenditure (excluding acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure as additional information
because we believe it is helpful to investors in highlighting trends in our business. Capital Expenditure (excluding
acquisitions) and Gross Capital Expenditure are not measures of financial performance under IFRS and should not be
considered as an alternative to measures of performance derived in accordance with IFRS. See "Presentation of Financial
_Information—Non-IFRS Measures" for additional information._

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risks**

We are exposed to various market and financial risks, including foreign currency risk, interest rate risk, credit risk
and liquidity risk. These risks and the manner in which we seek to mitigate them are summarized below and described in
more detail in note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to
the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements.


-----

**_Market Risks_**

We are exposed to market risk mainly as a result of financial instruments denominated in a foreign currency
(foreign currency risk) and our exposure to interest bearing liabilities such as loans (interest rate risk).

_Foreign currency risk_

Foreign currency risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows will fluctuate because of changes in foreign
exchange rates. Our exposure to the risk of changes in foreign exchange rates relates primarily to our operating activities
(when revenue or expenses and their resulting receivable/payable positions are denominated in a foreign currency).

The majority of our revenue (66.6% for the year ended December 31, 2022), expenses and obligations are
denominated in euro. However, we are exposed to currency risk mainly from our cash flows generated in Sweden, Norway,
the United Kingdom, Poland and the Czech Republic. We also incur currency risk on the net investment in our operations
in Sweden, Poland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Switzerland, Denmark, Norway and the United Kingdom.

Our management has determined, based on a risk assessment, to hedge some of these currency risks by using
certain forward-exchange contracts. This policy is intended to protect our financial position. For additional information on
foreign currency risk and our foreign exchange contracts, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28
to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial
Statements.

_Interest rate risk_

We are exposed to interest rate risk because entities in the Group borrow funds at both fixed and floating interest
rates. Our policy is to have a fixed/floating interest rate profile on the interest bearing liabilities which is fitting with the
nature of our assets. Hedging activities are evaluated regularly to align with our hedging policy. As most of the interest
bearing liabilities have a floating interest rate, we have contracted certain interest rate swaps so that we receive floating
interest and pay fixed interest. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, approximately 69% of the outstanding
principal amount of our Existing Term Loan B was hedged through February 2028 with €1,000 million in nominal amount
of interest rate swaps outstanding. For additional information on interest rate risk and our interest rate swaps, see note 7 to
the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial
Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements.

**_Credit Risk_**

Credit risk is the risk that we face when a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its
contractual obligations. Credit risk mainly arises on cash and cash equivalents and receivable balances from trade and other
receivables and other longer-term receivables.

As of June 30, 2023, amounts exposed to credit risk include non-current loans receivable amounting to €9,840
million, trade receivables amounting to €227.4 million, other receivables amounting to €38.8 million and cash and cash
equivalents amounting to €1.1 million. As of December 31, 2022, amounts exposed to credit risk include non-current loans
receivable amounting to €2.5 million, trade receivables amounting to €210.4 million, other receivables amounting to €31.1
million and cash and cash equivalents amounting to €17.2 million.

Substantially all of our cash at banks is held with high credit quality financial institutions with credit ratings of A(S&P) or higher.

As of June 30, 2023, no significant increase in credit risk has occurred with respect to the above noted non-current
loans receivable. The expected credit losses for these balances were computed based on a 12-month expected credit loss
and was estimated to be remote. For additional information on credit risk, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial
Statements, note 28 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements.

**_Liquidity Risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that we encounter difficulty in meeting our financial liabilities that are settled by
delivering cash or another financial asset. Our approach to managing liquidity is to ensure, as far as possible, that we will
meet our liabilities when they are due, under both normal and stressed conditions, without incurring unacceptable losses or
risking damage to our reputation. We manage our liquidity risk by maintaining sufficient cash and available credit facilities
through the continuous monitoring of future and actual cash flows and by matching the maturity profiles of our financial
assets and liabilities. For additional information, see note 7 to the HY 2023 Interim Financial Statements, note 28 to the
FY 2022 Financial Statements, note 4 to the FY 2021 Financial Statements and note 4 to the FY 2020 Financial Statements.

**Certain Differences Between Dutch GAAP and IFRS**

The FY 2021 Financial Statements and FY 2020 Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering
Memorandum have been prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP. The FY 2022 Financial Statements and HY 2023
Interim Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum were prepared in accordance with IFRS.
Certain differences exist between Dutch GAAP and IFRS that may be material to the financial information presented
therein.

The discussion set forth below summarizes certain differences identified between Dutch GAAP and IFRS as
applied by the Group, following a limited analysis of both sets of principles. For additional information on our first-time
adoption of IFRS, including reconciliations of certain financial information from Dutch GAAP to IFRS for the years ended
December 31, 2021 and 2022, see note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements. For a management reconciliation of our
financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 from Dutch GAAP to a more comparable basis with
our financial information for subsequent periods prepared in accordance with IFRS, see "—Reconciled Financial
_Information" below. See also "—Presentation of Financial Information" and "—Factors Affecting the Comparability of_
_our Results of Operations—Application of IFRS" above._

Prospective investors are advised to consult their professional advisors for an understanding of: (i) the differences
between Dutch GAAP, IFRS and other systems of generally accepted accounting principles and how those differences
might affect the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum; and (ii) the impact that future additions to,
or amendments of, IFRS may have on the financial information presented in this Offering Memorandum, our results of
operations and/or financial condition, as well as on the comparability of prior periods. See also "Risk Factors—Financial
_Risks—Our current financial statements are prepared in accordance with IFRS and are not comparable with our prior_
_financial statements prepared in accordance with Dutch GAAP."_

Some key differences between Dutch GAAP and IFRS, as they relate to the Group, are listed hereafter. For
additional information, see note 30 to the FY 2022 Financial Statements.

    - **Goodwill: Under Dutch GAAP, goodwill was capitalized and amortized on a straight-line basis.**
Goodwill under IFRS is required to be capitalized, however, no amortization thereof takes place. As a
result, we have reversed €46.5 million of goodwill amortization in 2021. See "—Reconciled Financial
_Information" below for information on the adjustments made for the Reconciled Financial Information_
for 2020.

    - **Leases: Under IFRS all leases are recognized in the balance sheet except for short term or low value**
lease contracts. Under Dutch GAAP financial lease contracts are presented "on-balance" and the
operational lease contracts are presented "off-balance". On the transition date (January 1, 2021), we
recognized €186.7 million of right of use assets and in total €183.9 million of lease liabilities. See "—
_Reconciled Financial Information" below for information on the adjustments made for the Reconciled_
Financial Information for 2020.

_Notes to the Reconciled Financial Information_

A. Goodwill

Under Dutch GAAP, goodwill is capitalized and amortized on a straight-line basis. Goodwill under IFRS is
required to be capitalized, however, no amortization thereof takes place. The amortization for the period presented has
therefore been reversed within profit or loss. The impact is a reversal of €46.7 million amortization for the year ended
December 31, 2020 presented under depreciation and amortization expenses.

B. Leases

At the date of transition to IFRS on January 1, 2021, we applied a single recognition and measurement approach
for all leases except for low-value asset leases and short-term leases (twelve months or less). As we started accounting
under IFRS as of January 1, 2021 for our entities in the Netherlands, we did not have the IFRS 16 accounting tools in place
in 2020. In the Nordics (entities acquired in our acquisition of Cramo), IFRS 16 accounting tools were in place in 2020. As
a result, for those countries where IFRS 16 accounting tools were not in place in 2020, we have made estimations based on
the actual lease expenses in 2020 and the Right of Use starting point at January 1, 2021. The total impact on the profit and
loss statement for the ended December 31, 2020 amounts to:

    - depreciation of right-of-use assets presented under depreciation and amortization expenses of €53.6
million were recognized in 2020;

    - lease expenses presented under material and services of €55.3 million were reversed in 2020;

    - lease liabilities interest expenses of €5.3 million presented under finance expense were recognized in
2020; and

    - the recognition of €0.3 million of revenue of subleases of real estate in 2020 which was presented under
revenue.


-----

C. Trade and other receivables

The adoption of IFRS fundamentally changed our accounting for impairment losses for financial assets by
replacing the incurred loss approach under Dutch GAAP with a forward-looking expected credit loss ("ECL") approach.
IFRS requires us to recognize an allowance for ECLs for all financial asset debt instruments not held at fair value through
profit or loss and contract assets. We assessed the impact of the change on transition date of January 1, 2021 to be
recognized in the statement of profit or loss for 2020 which has led to a decrease in net impairment losses on financial
assets in an amount of €1.2 million.

D. Revenue

Under Dutch GAAP, sales made through the DIY partner business are recognized on a net (agent) basis. The
application of IFRS 15 to these contracts has resulted in the recognition of revenue on a gross (principal) basis and
accordingly an increase in revenue was recognized in the 2020 financial year. We adjusted this by an increase of revenue
of €8.5 million and an equivalent decrease in material and services. We also adjusted revenue by €0.3 million for revenue
of subleases of real estate in 2020. See "—B. Leases" above.

E. Deferred tax

The various transitional adjustments (leases, trade and other receivables) results in different temporary differences.
Deferred tax adjustments are recognized in correlation to the underlying transaction in income tax expense. The total
adjustment amounts to €0.3 million additional tax expenses in 2020.

F. Defined benefit obligations

Defined benefit plan obligations are recognized and measured using the projected unit credit method (IAS19).
The pension expenses in 2020 related to defined benefit plans, which amounted to €0.8 million. This has been adjusted
under employee benefits expenses.

G. Statement of cash flows

Cash flows arising from payments of the principal portion of lease liabilities are classified as cash outflows from
financing activities. Therefore, cash inflows from operating activities increased by €50.1 million and cash outflows from
financing activities increased by the same amount for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**Overview**

The equipment rental industry plays a key role in the value chain of significant and economically important endmarkets, including maintenance, infrastructure, construction, energy and energy transition as well as consumer-facing
sectors.

Equipment rental companies provide customers with a range for products from larger equipment such as aerial
work platforms, excavators, earthmoving equipment and forklift trucks, to smaller equipment such as power saws, power
generators, scaffolding, ladders, and small pumps. Rental companies are also active in rental markets for containers,
sanitation, portable kitchens and trailers. In addition to providing equipment, many rental companies provide holistic
support for their customers through a range of services such as maintenance, in-service inspection, repair, transportation,
storage, compliance with health and safety regulations, insurance and training on the proper use of the equipment. The
provision of holistic support along with equipment rental is becoming increasingly important for rental companies as large
end-customers incrementally outsource those previously in-house services.

Primary customers typically include engineering, procurement, and construction ("EPC") contractors, industrial
companies, government entities, infrastructure facilitators, utilities, maintenance operators, construction companies as well
as homeowners, craftsmen and small and medium-sized enterprises. A large portion of the equipment rental customer base
comes from the industrial and the commercial construction sectors. Commercial construction rentals are geared towards
contractors conducting new-build and repair and renovation work who rent a wide range of equipment from power tools to
backhoes. Industrial rentals are geared towards businesses conducting routine plant maintenance as well as for projects that
require specialized tools such as welding equipment, power washing equipment, forklifts and other material handling
equipment. Additionally, craftsmen as well as events and media companies have increasingly relied on rental solutions for
operational equipment such as power generators, portable toilets and specialized craft equipment. In parallel, specialized
rental equipment are supplied for specific projects, such as transfer pump, site hut, security gate, site safe and industrial
lighting. Increasingly, rental equipment are also requested in connection with the response to emergency situations and
incidents, such as natural disasters and refugee crises.

We operate depots in 18 countries with our key geographic markets being Germany, the Netherlands, Sweden,
Finland and Belgium. The dynamics of the customer and geographic end markets we serve vary significantly, as described
below under "—Our Key Geographic Markets."

**Customer Value Proposition and Equipment Rental Business Model**

The long-term growth prospects for the equipment rental industry continue to be favorable, supported by
fundamental tailwinds as customers are increasingly renting (i.e., outsourcing) rather than owning operational equipment.
The shift to outsourcing is also driven by structural macroeconomic and regulatory factors that increase the attractiveness
of renting equipment. The advantages of equipment rental over ownership for companies includes:

    - **Cost and business flexibility: Equipment rental increases business flexibility by allowing companies to**
transform fixed costs into variable costs incurred on an as needed basis. In contrast, equipment ownership
entails a higher proportion of fixed costs and includes a number of ongoing costs in addition to the cost
of initial purchase, such as insurance, maintenance, in service inspection, repair, transportation and
storage and depreciation costs, which tend to increase over the life of the equipment. Equipment rental
also reduces the amount of capital required in comparison to purchasing equipment, reducing a
customer's exposure to credit market conditions and preserving capital for other investments, all of which
enables customers to focus on the core parts of their business.

    - **Equipment access and availability: Equipment rental gives customers access to a comprehensive range**
of equipment, including the latest generation of technology, allowing them to select the most appropriate
piece of equipment for the task at hand, which can improve safety, efficiency and quality. Equipment
rental also allows customers to benefit from a number of ancillary services provided by rental companies,
including training, safety testing, regulatory compliance, logistical support and consultation on
equipment selection. In addition, when renting from rental companies with a large network of branches,
customers are able to optimize their logistics flows to and from their worksites.


-----

    - **Climate change awareness: Rental of equipment is part of the larger developing circular economy,**
where equipment is rented by many customers over its life cycle allowing for better utilization rates while
the rental company maintains control over the equipment's good functioning order through a program of
maintenance and regular inspections. Equipment rental allows customers to be a part of this circular
economy and reduce their carbon emissions by reducing the overall size of their equipment fleet, limiting
their carbon footprint to the use of such equipment only and utilizing newer and more sustainable
equipment compared with company-owned equipment.

    - **Health and safety: Equipment rental generally enhances the operational safety of customers by**
providing modern, well-serviced equipment. In addition, equipment rental allows customers to more
easily benefit from the mechanization and automation of many of their operations, including hazardous
tasks, by providing access to and training on specialized equipment, such as power access tools.

In the European rental market, the key performance criteria mentioned by rental equipment customers consist of
the availability of equipment, equipment quality, location, flexibility, and safety, which can be more important than price
in certain markets. Small and medium enterprises ("SME") tend to place orders via sales representatives or through direct
engagement with a depot representative, while medium to large companies are increasingly ordering through online
platforms.

On average, a majority of rental equipment clients use two or more equipment rental companies primarily as a
result of assortment, availability and price differences for each product segment.

The economic value-add of a rental equipment provider is derived from the benefit from a lower break-even period
and enhanced returns compared to regular equipment purchasers as a result of more efficient fleet utilization, benefit from
centralized procurement contracts resulting in lower purchase prices, centralized and lower annual repair and maintenance
costs, benefit from higher resale value after the useful life and equipment financing benefits due to economies of scale.

Northern, Southern and Eastern Europe. The UK, Germany and France are the largest European markets for rental
equipment with their combined share estimated at approximately 60% of the total market size. According to the ERA 2022
Market Report, the market is highly fragmented with approximately 58% of European rental market revenue generated by
small firms, approximately 23% generated by middle-size companies and nearly 20% generated by large companies
(defined as companies with more than 250 employees).
