**Strategies**

Our business strategy focuses on profitable growth, further enhancing operational efficiency, strengthening our
market position in all segments, expanding our service offerings, developing innovative digital solutions to improve
customer efficiency and promoting corporate social responsibility.

**_Achieve a leading position in all our markets and become a leading partner for our customers_**

We intend to continue working to provide a high quality, one-stop-shop experience for both individual consumers
and businesses, while ensuring that our entire rental range of products meets our customers' evolving demands, in order to
achieve a leading market position in each of the markets we address.

We believe that we are well-positioned to become the leading partner of our customers in all the geographies we
serve. We believe that our customers already recognize us as a preferred one-stop-shop for their rental needs, primarily due
to our diversification across products, end markets, general and specialist rental, and our strong European geographic
coverage. Our acquisition of Cramo has demonstrated our ambition to keep strengthening and expanding our geographic
coverage and diversifying our service offering.

We believe we can achieve a leading position in our markets through our strong, long-term partnerships with our
customers. In order to strengthen our customer relationships and remain our customers' preferred rental partner, we aim to
provide full turn-key solutions, ranging from providing generalist tools to more specialized equipment (including site huts,
site safes, traffic sets and sanitation), in addition to value-added services such as logistics. For example, in 2021, we
delivered full service rental solutions for a wind farm project in Lithuania by providing site huts, construction equipment
and special tools, in addition to access control, on-site maintenance, and helping with planning, transportation, delivery.
Since 2022, we provide full turnkey solutions for an automotive Gigafactory located in Berlin-Brandenburg. We combine
our proximity to customers and our understanding of their needs in order to continue providing our customers with valueadded services and products. Finally, we intend to continue pursuing our fleet investment strategy, which aims to maintain
a complete range of sustainable and safe rental equipment.

**_Grow through a combination of organic development and bolt-on acquisitions_**

We have achieved an impressive track record of both sales and EBITDA growth through a strategic combination
of strong organic growth and the successful integration of both our transformative and smaller bolt-on acquisitions.
Through our acquisition strategy in particular, we have expanded to cover new geographic markets and have diversified
our catalogue of products and services.

We believe we have significant opportunities to continue growing organically due to our comprehensive network
of 759 depots and more than 3,100 DIY shop-in-shops across Europe as of June 30, 2023. We intend to increase the density
of our network in less concentrated regions which we believe have a strong potential of profitable growth through our clear
greenfield expansion strategy.


-----

We also intend to continue evaluating strategic acquisition targets to further strengthen and expand our operations
and customer base, to selectively enter new markets over time, in particular in geographic areas with low rental company
concentration to increase opportunities for upselling and cross-selling our products. . In pursuing such acquisitions, we
maintain the same disciplined, targeted, and opportunistic acquisition investment criteria that have historically enabled us
to successfully identify acquisition targets and profitably acquire and integrate them.

Successful integration of acquisitions is key to our strategy, and we believe we are well-positioned to integrate
future acquisitions efficiently and profitably. We have dedicated integration teams supported by local teams with superior
knowledge of their local markets to develop synergies in our fleet management, expedite the completion and integration of
acquisitions and position us to achieve our long-term success.

**_Drive digital innovation to increase productivity for our customers and improve our operational efficiency_**

We have developed and intend to continue to develop digital services in order to improve our customers'
experience and boost our operational performance.

We believe that we are a leader in the development of new, innovative digital business models in our industry.
We have developed and deployed new types of data- and connectivity-based solutions to connect our people, internal
processes and fleet to our customers, such as our new smart application for mobile devices, "Equipment Pool", which
improves customers' access to equipment and machines, while reducing transportation times to and from customers'
construction sites . We believe that we can leverage our digital processes and use of data in a customer-focused manner in
order to improve communication between our employees and our customers, better identify customers' needs and facilitate
interactions and transactions with customers.

Although we already have improved processes and digital tools in place to optimize our customers' experience,
we intend to continue enhancing our rental websites, including those of Cramo, Boels Rental and IQ Pass, to add further
equipment data and specifications and combine our general and specialist rental fleet in a single platform. We believe that
such technological capabilities positions us to achieve the full potential of our one-stop-shop solutions.

We also intend to continue leveraging digital tools to streamline and boost efficiency in our internal systems. For
example, we have implemented a single group-wide financial system to monitor our cash flows and key performance
indicators. We have also implemented our group-wide One Boels strategy in order to continue harmonizing systems and
processes based on four pillars: (i) One IT approach; (ii) One financial organization, (iii) One fleet and procurement
organization and (iv) One HR approach and organization. We have developed our One Boels strategy as a clear, distinct,
and strong organization that focuses not only on our customers' needs, but also boosts our efficiency. We intend to continue
enhancing our operational systems and processes to increase our operational and procurement efficiency, improve our
strategic relationships with OEMs, strengthen our fleet management and negotiating position for strategic procurement and
maintenance of our fleet, and enhance our employee retention.

**_Maintain top-tier performance as a leading rental company_**

We aim to maintain our operational performance by systematically improving and optimizing fleet usage,
composition and performance. Historically, we have had a more centralized business model where our rental fleet was
managed centrally to optimize the allocation of equipment, while local managers organized by countries and depots offered
knowledge of local markets. Cramo, on the other side, has historically had a more decentralized business group structure,
where operating decisions were made at the country and business-unit level. With the integration of Cramo, we have
developed a synergized approach, which aims to combine the best practices of both organizations by centralizing key
operations such as procurement or fleet management, while we keep a flexible and locally oriented commercial approach
for each market and geography.

We believe that this approach, together with our close cooperation with, and monitoring of, our depots, business
units and departments, positions us to achieve our strategy, whilst retaining our disciplined and flexible business and
financial models.

**_Reinforce our commitments to the environment, safety, quality and corporate responsibility_**

We are committed to promoting and maintaining corporate sustainability and responsibility as a core component
of our business. We intend to continue being a leading climate- and resource-efficient rental company, paving the way to
enhance sustainability in the rental industry and to reduce our environmental footprint throughout our value chain. We
believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our impact on
the environment while efficiently operating our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and
demands for more sustainable solutions.


-----

We are convinced that maintaining an adequate corporate governance policy is a prerequisite to structure the
organization efficiently and effectively and achieve our strategic goals. We also believe that our sustainability policy helps
us to manage risks and to consider the interests of all our stakeholders, including our shareholders, our employees and our
customers. We discuss our material sustainability topics, focus areas and strategic targets twice a year with our Strategic
Board and our Operations Board, and periodically with the Sustainability Steering Committee that we have implemented
to help us achieve our sustainability goals. For a further discussion of our commitment to environmental, social and
governance matters and our targets for 2025, see "Business—Environmental, Social and Governance."

**History and Development**

Before Boels was incorporated in the Netherlands in 1977, our family started the business with four garage boxes,
lending tools to friends and acquaintances. In 1980, we opened our first formal office in Sittard, and in the 1990s, we
expanded to Belgium and Germany and began supplying mobile kitchens and in-shop rental points in DIY stores. As we
continued on our trajectory of organic growth and expansion, Pierre Boels Jr. became CEO in 1996 and implemented our
European growth strategy. In 2000, we commenced a full-service offering with OneCall, which provides customers with a
single point of contact for their rental needs. We celebrated 25 years in business in 2002 with 650 employees and 65 depots
in three countries. In 2004, we opened our 100th depot.

During the early 2000s, we strategically expanded into countries and activities that were complementary to our
original footprint and product and service base. In 2007, we commenced operations in Austria, Slovakia, the Czech
Republic and Poland, and at the end of 2011, we acquired Baurent Baumaschinen Miet-Service GmbH, a construction
machinery and equipment rental company, expanding our presence in Germany. In 2015, we acquired leading specialist
companies in climate and energy rental, shop-in-shop rental and earthmoving equipment. In 2017 we opened our 400[th]
depot. In 2017 and 2018, we completed additional strategic acquisitions in the United Kingdom, while also adding to our
industrial rental operation by acquiring Abird.

The year 2020 marked an important point in our history, where our fleet exceeded the €2.0 billion purchase value
mark for the first time reflecting both our organic growth and strategic acquisitions. We believe we became the second
largest equipment rental company in Europe based on revenue for 2022, all within 50 years of selling our first product, an
11-kilo breaker. That year, we acquired the listed Finnish rental company Cramo, integrating the five Central European
countries where Cramo's presence overlapped with Boels and raising the overall number of countries in which we operated
in to 18. In 2021, we launched our sustainability motto "Orange is the new green," highlighting our commitment to assisting
our customers in building and working with lower emissions. In 2022, we acquired Eekels Pompen, a Dutch specialist
pump company, expanding our product portfolio. That same year, we launched our One Boels program to integrate
overhead activities, such as finance, HR, fleet management and IT throughout our entire network into the Boels
organization. Our expansion through strategic acquisitions continued through June 30, 2023 with the acquisition of Illumin8
in the UK and BAS Maskinutleie, Hyresbutiken AB, and Kraftx AB in the Nordics. For further details about our recent
acquisitions, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors
_Affecting Results of Operations—Acquisitions, Geographic Expansion and Depot Openings."_

**Products and Services**

Our core product offering consists of general and specialist rental equipment in addition to complementary
products and services, as well as the selling of used rental equipment as an integral part of our fleet management. Our used
equipment sales help maintain optimal levels of fleet availability, age and variety. In the twelve months ended June 30,
2023, our revenue was comprised of approximately 70% revenue from equipment rental and approximately 30% revenue
from sales of products and other services.

**_Equipment Rental_**

We are a leading provider of rental equipment and services in Europe for various sectors, including civil
engineering, industrial, construction, infrastructure, warehousing and events. We offer a wide range of products consisting
of approximately 860,000 unique articles across 30 product groups, including tools, machinery, modular buildings, climate
control, lifting and hoisting, surveying, safety, traffic services, earthworks, cleaning, flooring, and sanitation. Our rental
product portfolio consists of two segments: general rental and specialist rental. As of June 30, 2023, we have 681 general
rental depots and 78 specialist rental depots.

In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, general rental generated 72% of our total revenue, and specialist rental
(including DIY) generated 28% of our total revenue, comprised of 25% generated by specialist rental (excluding DIY) and
3% generated by DIY. For the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, generalist rental generated 73%, 74% and
73% of our total revenue, respectively. For the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021 and 2020, specialist rental (including
DIY) generated 27%, 26% and 27% of our total revenue, respectively.


-----

**_General Rental_**

As part of our general product line, we offer the following categories of equipment to rent to our diverse endmarket customers:

    - **Access Equipment, including scissor lifts (both battery and diesel-powered), passenger lifts, aerial work**
platforms, scaffolding, edge protection, and ladders and steps.

    - **Earthmoving, including plate compactors, rammers, dumpers and loaders, some of which form part of**
our Zero Emissions Evolution line of products.

    - **Energy and Climate, including heating through diesel, electric, gas, or carbon neutral sources, mobile**
boilers, air handlers, cooling systems, air humidification and purification and dust management.

    - **Materials Handling, including cranes, forklifts, telehandlers, hoists, winches, jacks, pallet trucks,**
trailers and conveyors, as well as accessories and rigging.

    - **Site Huts and Site Prep, including lasers, levelling instruments, GPS technology, power supply**
equipment, event fencing, passenger and goods hoists, and complementary security services such as
access control, crowd management and surveillance.

    - **Tools, including generators, transformers and load banks, lighting towers, battery packs, cables,**
compressors, pumps, hoses and fuel tanks.

**_Specialist Rental_**

Through our specialist rental line, we provide support for a variety of customer segments that require specialist
knowledge for applications and products. Our specialist product line consists of a wide range of tools and equipment to
meet some of the more niche needs of our customers, and comprises:

    - **Accommodation and sanitary facilities, including interconnectable units, mobile units, storage**
containers, furnishings, sanitary facilities, and fittings and accessories.

    - **Compressors and pneumatics, including compressors, all of which are equipped with a built-in**
aftercooler, pneumatic drills, hoisting cushions, torque and impact wrenches, concrete scarifiers, sanders
and paint sprayers.

    - **Crowd control and LED screens, including turnstiles, personnel access gateways for events and**
construction sites, and mobile and fully rotational LED screens in a variety of sizes, which are operational
within an hour.

    - **Portable kitchens, including hot kitchens, cold kitchens, dishwasher kitchens, cooling and freezer units,**
food service counters, and other kitchen equipment.

    - **Site accommodation,** including a more niche offering of our general modular product line, such as units
that can be set up as offices, dressing rooms, storage rooms, canteens, first aid stations, and more. These
modular units are often almost fully recyclable and more environmentally friendly.

    - **Site preparation and logistics, including tailor-made service plans for our customers' projects, which**
include advice, rental, assembly and disassembly.

    - **Survey and laser, including construction and sewer lasers, levelling instruments, GPS rovers, thermal**
imaging cameras, gas detectors, walkie-talkies and temperature meters. For these products, we offer the
ability not only to rent but also to lease and buy measuring instruments, accessories and consumables.

    - **Traffic engineering, including trailer mounted variable message signs, barriers, and LED screens.**

We have strategically grown our specialist rental offering having completed 12 acquisitions of specialist rental companies
since 2015, which has contributed to a CAGR of approximately 31% in our revenue from specialist rental between 2015
and the twelve months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, we have increased our revenue from specialist rental organically
through cross-selling between specialisms, resulting in a CAGR of approximately 8.6% in specialist organic revenue
between 2020 and the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.


-----

**_Complementary Services and Product Ranges_**

We complement our broad range of quality rental product offerings with service solutions and additional product
ranges to support our customers through every step of their project implementation. Our services and additional products
cover and/or include, where applicable:

    - **Onsite rental, where we provide a temporary rental point at our customers' sites and locations.**

    - **Calamities, including assistance with emergencies or disasters such as power cuts, heat waves, floods or**
epidemics. Such help can include the opening of temporary depots and the rapid redeployment of large
portions of our fleet, including fencing, emergency road signs and power generators. While individual
products mirror those in our general and specialist rental segments, under this range they are organized
and marketed for the needs resulting from specific emergencies, such as providing equipment and set up
for COVID-19 vaccination sites during the pandemic.

    - **Long-term rental, including equipment and machine leases from one to five years, paired with**
maintenance and inspection.

    - **Project management and implementation, whereby our project managers assist customers in**
organizing the necessary equipment, personnel and other requirements for their complex projects,
including an HSE plan. As part of this service, our customers can also benefit from our assistance with
installation and maintenance, with specialists available 24/7.

    - **Site management, including facility services such as security, installation, cleaning and waste**
management.

    - **Service and maintenance, including equipment inspections, certifications and checks, and assistance**
with malfunctions.

    - **Fuel management, which leverages smart meter technology so that we can monitor our customers' fuel**
levels remotely. As part of this service, our suppliers periodically visit our customers to refuel their
diesel-powered equipment.

    - **OneCall, our customers' single point of contact for all their rental needs, including questions regarding**
our product offerings, reservations and even invoicing.

    - **Training courses, including equipment training courses, safety courses and more custom training**
courses such as toolbox presentations, tailored to our customers' particular needs.

    - **Product sales, including consumables and machine accessories. We also sell used machines and tools.**

**Customers**

We offer our products and services to a broad and diversified customer base of more than 670,000 customers who
generated revenue in the twelve months as of June 30, 2023. Our customers range from large international companies to
small- and medium-sized businesses, craftsmen and retail clients, who operate in many sectors, such as industrial, offshore,
warehousing, infrastructure, chemical, events, construction, and infrastructure.

Regardless of their size or industry, many of our customers have time-sensitive and complex projects, and we
believe that our vast network of depots and wide range of general and specialist offerings allow us to meet our clients'
needs.

We also believe that increased use of data and digitization of processes can have a positive impact on our customer
experience and are focusing on investing in solutions that improve customer centricity and processes. We continuously
work to improve our rental website and portal (MyBoels) by updating equipment data and specifications, for example
combining specialist items into a one-stop solution platform where our customers can access information on equipment
availability, reservations, contracts, product details and invoicing across our general and specialist segments. We have
implemented several data-driven dashboards to facilitate our monitoring of KPIs, progress and trends in order to better
identify and anticipate issues. For certain major customers with high transaction volumes, we have built custom Enterprise


-----

Resource Planning ("ERP") and procurement system integrations, which allow them to connect to our IT system for access
to our electronic catalogue, order-to-cash integration, and e-invoicing. Our sales team actively promotes this service as part
of our rental offering to increase efficiency of renting across all of our depots for our large clients.

With our largest key accounts and managed customers, we negotiate framework agreements establishing pricing
policies for our equipment. These agreements typically have a duration of one to three years. Certain framework agreements
contain discounts based upon volume commitments made by the customer. Smaller and more localized customers are
typically subject to our standard terms and conditions.

We have a diversified customer base, with our top 10 customers accounting for approximately 7.4% of our revenue
for the year ended December 31, 2022 and no single customer accounting for more than 2% of our revenue over the same
time period. As a result of our diversification efforts over the past three years, we have decreased the percentage of our
revenue derived from our top 10 largest clients. Furthermore, our customer base is loyal and has a high retention rate, with
our top 10 customers having an average relationship with us of approximately 20 years.

We believe that we have limited concentrations of credit risk in trade receivables as a result of the spread of our
business across customers, markets and regions. Sales on account are only made to customers that meet the Group's credit
rating requirements. Goods and services are sold subject to payment terms, the majority of which range between 15 to 60
days. A different payment period may apply to major customers, in which case additional security is demanded, including
guarantees. Credit risks are routinely monitored by reviewing credit limits and payment terms per customer. Outstanding
trade receivables are regularly monitored and legal action is taken against debtors with long outstanding balances. Overall,
we believe that our exposure to long-outstanding balances exceeding the post-paid terms is not significant.

**Sales and Marketing**

We maintain and invest in a strong sales and marketing organization, which we believe enables us to both maintain
close and loyal relationships with our existing customers and expand our reach to attract and retain new customers. Our
client management system operates on a tiered system based on size and geography. Within Boels, our local and small
business customers are generally served by local depot managers and commercial rental employees who provide our
customers with counter service and information on the rental process and equipment. Midsize customers are served by
regional account managers and large key accounts are managed by key account managers who often operate internationally.

Our sales and marketing departments, combined with innovative digital solutions, work to anticipate our clients'
needs based on feedback from both customers, original equipment manufacturers ("OEMs") and suppliers, as well as
industry research and trends. All of our customer interaction and feedback is stored in a centralized Salesforce platform,
using cloud services across sales, services and marketing. The Salesforce platform is used and updated on a daily basis by
approximately 2,500 employees at Boels working in rental, sales and services.

We believe that our use of digital solutions offers our customers convenient, fast and tailored products and
services. Our self-service portals allow our customers to view their rented products, pricing, contract, invoicing and delivery
information. Since the launch of the MyBoels portal, customers have been able to access more granular data on their rentals
such as fuel and battery levels and service errors.

For our major customers (including in the industries of infrastructure and construction), we have implemented
building information modelling ("BIM") models, which are digital platforms that create and manage 3D models for
building and infrastructure projects. BIM models are relevant at all phases of construction projects, from initial planning
and design to construction and ongoing maintenance. The BIM models of our rental products are stored in our product
information management systems, which are accessible through the MyBoels portal.

In 2022, we invested in a project to optimize customer experience and engagement with our local listings, which
aims to provide customers with immediate digital access to the nearest depot. As a result, each depot's opening hours,
address and contact details are updated in real time across all our marketing channels and related online sources.

**Rental Fleet**

As of June 30, 2023, we had a fleet of approximately 860,000 pieces of serialized rental equipment units, with a
purchase value of €2.8 billion. We strive to offer a wide range of equipment and tools, representing 30 product groups
across generalist and specialized equipment and tools. We strongly focus on lighter equipment, which positions us on the
'fit out', 'maintain' and 'operate' phases of the asset cycle. As of June 30, 2023, our fleet is comprised of approximately 39%
tools, 27% energy and climate, 13% material handling, 11% site huts and site preparation, 5% earthmoving and 4% access
equipment. In the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated €813 million in rental revenue from our fleet only
(excluding revenue on fleet items), of which tools and light equipment generated 48% (comprised of tools generating 16%,


-----

material handling generating 12% and energy and climate generating 20%), access equipment generated 25%, earthmoving
generated 13% and site huts and site preparation 14%.

With the goal of providing the European market with the best and latest equipment, we aim to invest strategically
in high-quality equipment that adheres to strict environmental and safety performance standards. In the year ended
December 31, 2022 and the six months ended June 30, 2023, investments in our fleet increased the number of serialized
rental items by approximately 6% and 3%, respectively, reflecting a broadening our existing assortment and our continued
investment in the Eco-label fleet to meet higher market demands for electrical, hybrid and battery-powered equipment with
high sustainability standards. We have continued to expand our fleet to include Eco-Label, Zero Emission, and ZeroEmission Evolution offerings. Machines and tools with the Eco-Label are less harmful to the environments in which they
operate in terms of emissions, vibrations and noise. As a result, they are better for the health of the user and local residents.
Zero Emission machines and tools that are manufactured to not emit carbon dioxide and Zero-Emission Evolution machines
and tools are those which we believe are at the forefront of technical development and make a larger impact in reducing
our customers environmental footprint. Examples of these include larger telehandlers, certain types of dumpers, and 4x4
heavy terrain scissor lifts.

For a further discussion of our fleet management investment decisions, see "—Fleet Management."

We have a well invested fleet as evidenced by the young weighted average age of our fleet which was 53 months
as of June 30, 2023, compared to 54 months as of December 31, 2022, which we believe will allow more flexibility in our
capital expenditures over the near to medium term.

**Fleet Management**

The asset management strategy for our extensive fleet that we have developed is based on a diversified deployment
of equipment. We work to provide a one-stop-shop experience for our customers and aim to ensure that our rental range is
available when needed, all while striving to minimize time and costs of delivery of equipment to customers and maximize
economies of scale and fleet utilization performance. As part of our strategy, we divide our equipment into several
subgroups which we believe enables us to analyze the most efficient and strategic routes for deployment, in addition to
targeting the best possible use for our customers. Our fleet categories (Access, Earthmoving, Energy and Climate, Materials
Handling, Site Huts and Site Prep, and Tools) are split into subcategories based on the characteristics of each item. By
tracking maintenance costs and fuel consumption, among other metrics, we believe we are able to determine which piece
of equipment is best suited for the job at the lowest cost and emissions. An increasing number of our fleet items are equipped
with telematics, allowing us to track more data and provide our customers with up-to-date metrics on their usage on our
recently launched MyBoels portal. Furthermore, we monitor fleet location, utilization and other metrics in one central
system. This allows us to have full visibility on individual depot performance, maintain appropriate inventory levels, and
manage fleet allocation across our networks as well as plan and monitor capital expenditures.

**_Digital innovation_**

Our fleet management system tracks the complete life cycle of any rental asset at our disposal by serializing the
vast majority of items within our fleet.

Data from information technology systems provides us with a comprehensive overview of the health, profitability
and productivity of our fleet. Utilizing this data allows us to provide recommendations to our customers concerning which
machinery might meet their requirements best. Additionally, in each depot we keep a record of each missed rental caused
by an item being unavailable either in a local depot or in our fleet more broadly. We believe this allows us to better
anticipate local demand and further optimize our logistics system.

We invest in innovative technology that enables us to not only track our rental items on a continuous basis but
also to process fleet maintenance and repairs efficiently and with relatively low administrative costs. We believe this allows
us to promptly register any equipment part for maintenance, thereby reducing duplicate purchases, as well as reducing the
frequency of asset audits, and rapidly identify lost items. In 2022, we fully integrated digital document management in our
fleet management system for all rental items, including with respect to all test certificates and CE declarations. Therefore,
this system now allows us to track important documentation with respect to legal or regulatory compliance and further
work to enhance our quality control and assurance, while reducing costs and equipment downtime through regular
maintenance checks and repair.

**_Procurement_**

Our position as a leader in the European rental market has enabled us to create strategic relationships with our
OEMs. Because we primarily employ a centralized procurement strategy, and due to our close relationships with our OEMs,
we believe that we are able to influence product development at the stage of manufacturing, so that we can remain at the
forefront of product innovation. For example, we have collaborated with our OEMs on various product improvements for
our rental equipment, including the standardization of lighting units, type and positioning of support wheels and the
placement of protective brackets, suspension points and lift points to aid in loading. This procurement strategy has also
provided us with the ability to negotiate prices, better analyze constraints in supply and explore ground-breaking
technological developments. While 2022 marked a challenging year in terms of supply chain constraints, our procurement
strategy allowed us to mitigate their effects on our operations. See also "—Suppliers" below.

**_Life cycle management_**

Our fleet management strategy also offers services across the entire life cycle of our equipment units, including
long-term rental, equipment servicing, and the resale of the equipment at the end of its financial or economic lifetime. The
digitalization of our system has facilitated our fleet maintenance and repair strategy. For each numbered item in our fleet,
we keep track of the total cost of ownership, which allows us to determine which brands or items are most efficient from a
cost/quality perspective. Additionally, we believe this data enables us to determine the optimal time to sell to avoid
increased maintenance costs for ourselves while still offering the buyer a quality tool that can last. We may also decide to
sell certain equipment sooner in cases where there is insufficient rental demand for such products. We sell our used
equipment through various channels, of which direct sales from our warehouse and auction sales are the most important.
We generally sell our used equipment outside of our principal markets, and occasionally we may need to sell equipment as
scrap.

The disposal of any piece of equipment from the fleet is a technical decision made by a technical manager based
on analysis, recorded metrics, and historical lifetime expectations. We have established metrics and guidelines for each
category of equipment that help determine the desired replacement cycle. Most metrics are based on repair costs relative
to rental income, utilization rate and age.

**_Strategic investments_**

When in line with our growth strategy or otherwise key to overall performance, we invest in integrating and
updating our fleet and we are able to react with agility to optimize our investments in response to changes in demand. For
example, in 2020, shortly after the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, we substantially reduced our capital expenditures and
focused on achieving the synergies from the Cramo acquisition. Through consolidating depots in certain regions and
increasing the density of our network in others, we were able to increase the utilization rates of our fleet. Following the
Cramo acquisition, we also relocated equipment in order to generate better returns. In 2021 and 2022, we invested
substantially in updating our fleet, which we believe not only increased our revenue and results, but also increased our
flexibility and allowed us to react more quickly to increased market demand as end-market activity picked up. For a further
discussion of our capital expenditures during the periods under review, see "Management's Discussion and Analysis of
_Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Results of Operations—Capital Expenditures, Fleet_
_Age and Equipment Disposals."_

**Suppliers**

We employ a centralized procurement model to leverage our scale. Alongside our OEMs, we plan and develop
the equipment and machines we believe are needed in our markets and market segments in Europe, whether general or
specialist.

We believe our long-lasting relationships with large and recognized OEMs allow us to obtain useful information
on new product innovations and assess market demand. Together with our OEMs, we analyze the time horizon for the next
three years in terms of market demand whereby we address our requirements in terms of quality, safety and low
maintenance costs. Our relationships with OEMs not only allows us to negotiate better prices, but it also give us insights
on the availability issues that may occur due to shortages of materials. In 2022, the equipment markets suffered from supply
chain shortages. Due to our excellent relationships with our OEMs, we were able to successfully navigate these shortages.
See "—Competitive Strengths—Well-invested fleet focused on smaller equipment with strong unit economics and robust
_fleet management and digital capabilities" for additional information. Additionally, the sheer volume of our fleet provides_
important data to the OEMs on their equipment, which we believe gives us additional leverage in managing our relationship
with our OEM suppliers.

We do not consider ourselves dependent on any single supplier, with most pieces of equipment available from
multiple different suppliers with whom we have a relationship. As of December 31, 2022, our top 10 suppliers accounted
for approximately 11.1% of our total purchases for that period, with no single supplier representing more than 3% of
purchases for that period.

Our hub-and-spoke, decentralized business model enables a diversified customer reach, allowing for increased
efficiency and flexibility in operations and an expansive physical coverage. With this extensive network, we are able to be
closer to our customers and their projects, whether for pick-up and return or project delivery. We believe that from an
operational standpoint, this model reduces transport time and emissions, which from a service perspective results in shorter
delivery and quicker response times for our customers.

Our network of depots has grown significantly over the course of the past decade through a combination of organic
growth and strategic acquisitions. Our network management is dynamic and the decision to open a branch is driven by our
analysis of the interaction of the proposed branch and our existing network, the conditions in the local market and the
competition within that market. Whether we open a new branch or acquire an existing network depends on the level of
saturation in that market and whether acquisitions can provide us a level of penetration that would take too long to develop
organically. Branches may be merged or closed based on the market environment (if, for example, a large construction


-----

project concludes or an industrial site closes) or excess proximity to another branch following an acquisition. We may also
relocate branches in light of the development of cities or the evolution of infrastructure, or to optimize our geographical
coverage.

We implement periodic network optimization plans to enhance the profitability of our depot network through
better coordination of commercial activities and capital expenditures, pooling of resources, integrating overhead and backoffice activities between regions, improved exchanges of staff and equipment among branches and enhanced depot and
hub positioning.

Our depots are generally located around cities, particularly in the Nordics where economic activities are
concentrated in urban areas. While our depots generally offer the same equipment, in certain industrial or more rural areas
our depots may carry slightly different inventory to anticipate local demand.

Our depots operate under the Boels and Cramo brands.

**Employees**

As of June 30, 2023, we had over 7,400 permanent employees.

Our employees perform the following functions, among others: sales and marketing operations, maintenance and
parts operations, rental operations, technical service and office and administrative support.

Our employees are a core part of our business and we invest in their development and training, which are key
priorities to ensure our customers consistently receive high-quality products and services. We place a strong emphasis on
employee training, including safety and competence-based training, and strive to support our employees' career growth.

We operate a defined contribution plan for our employees and pay contributions to pension funds and insurance
companies on a contractual basis. Besides these contributions, we have no other obligations to pay further contributions by
virtue of these pension plans. Of our foreign group companies, only Boels Rental Germany GmbH, Cramo AB and Cramo
Services Sweden AB have their own pension plans as a result of a historic pension arrangement applicable to a specific
group of former Cramo AG employees. These plans qualify as a defined benefit plan in accordance with IAS 19.

Certain of our employees are represented by various works councils, unions and other employee representative
bodies and are subject to collective bargaining or works council agreements. For certain courses of action, we require our
works councils' and unions' consent, and for others, we are required to ensure our works councils and unions are informed
of the processes or have an advisory role in undertaking such actions, as applicable. We believe we have a strong
collaboration with our employees, works councils and unions based on clear processes and trust.

**Information Technology**

Over recent years, we have invested significantly in various IT systems to improve our internal operations, our
sales and marketing processes, and our interactions with our customers. Operationally, we employ a centralized and robust
information technology platform, which we refer to as One IT, whereby we strive to provide digitization, connectivity and
innovation across our operations in a secure fashion. For marketing and sales, we have implemented and invested in
improving various digital platforms to provide our customers with access to our products, such as self-service portals, ecommerce websites, and BIM models. We also employ the use of an optimized Salesforce CRM system to store customer
information, interactions, and needs.

In 2021, as part of our "One Boels" strategy, we focused on integrating Cramo's IT operations in Central and
Northern Europe into the integrated hardware and software backbone of our IT systems, covering 5,000 workstations. In
addition to undertaking this integration, and improving our customer experience on our Boels website, we implemented
numerous digital programs in line with our IT strategy. These included our "Customer Excellence Programs" and mobile
applications such as the Logistic application, Boels traffic service application, disaster management application, and waste
data application. The customer applications and portals provide real-time information to the customers at each stage of the
rental process from product search, reservation, ordering and logistics to invoicing. As part of this IT strategy, we also
invested in developments to our company dashboards to improve our performance monitoring capacity with respect to
operations, finance and HR and with respect to compliance measures, such as cash register and security systems. In
addition, we implemented three additional data systems in 2021, including a Robotics Process Automation ("RPA") system
(which automates certain manual processes), a Product Information Management ("PIM") system (which we use to help
us process large amounts of complex product information and to distribute this data through their relevant channels, both
internally and externally), and a Digital Asset Management ("DAM") system (which has the capacity to organize and
manage digital content and assets for communication purposes, including brand logos, designs, images, video,
presentations, and text files).


-----

In 2022, we introduced a new company-wide digital workspace (social intranet) for all countries, which is geared
towards improving tailor-made internal communication and stimulating collaboration and interaction between all
colleagues and across all departments. The intranet is a single platform for employees that contains information, news
articles, HQ support, product information and best practices.

In addition, we operate the One Boels IT team, which is located in Sittard and Stockholm. The main IT systems
are SAP4H, Salesforce CRM, SAP SuccessFactors and One Digital with SAP Commerce Cloud. The integration was built
with MuleSoft technology and Microsoft Azure. The Backend ERP systems of Cramo and Boels (including SAP4H) are
fully integrated with the Digital Frontend Portals and Salesforce using MuleSoft enterprise integration and Azure
technology. Through this technology, our employees and customers are able to view the same real-time data as it relates to
sales, support and field use.

**Intellectual Property**

We use several trademarks, mainly including the "Boels," "Cramo," "Niebo," "RENTPARTNER," "TRENDRENT," "IQ-Pass" and "Eekels Pompen" brands, all of which enjoy high brand recognition in their home markets. Our
"Boels" trademark, and several of our other key trademarks are registered in the countries where we do business, including
the UK, the Netherlands and other members of the European Union.

Our trademarks, domain names, copyrights and all of our other intellectual property are important assets that
afford protection to our business. Our success depends to a degree upon our ability to protect and preserve certain
proprietary aspects of our technology and our brands. To ensure we meet that objective, we control access to our proprietary
technology. Our employees and consultants enter into confidentiality and nondisclosure agreements with us. We protect
our rights to proprietary technology and confidential information in our business arrangements with third parties through
confidentiality and intellectual property and business agreements.

We hold a number of third-party patent and intellectual property license agreements that afford us rights under
third-party patents, technology and other intellectual property, including for the use of certain material software
applications. We cannot ensure that future license agreements can or will be obtained or renewed on acceptable terms, or
at all.

**Environmental, Social and Governance**

We are subject to comprehensive and frequently changing local, national and European Union-level laws and
regulations, including those relating to emissions to the air, pollution of water and land, and the handling, storage,
transportation, use and disposal of hazardous materials and wastes. Among other laws and regulations, we are subject to
Regulation for Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH), the Energy Efficiency
Directive (EED), and the Plastic Regulation, Batteries Regulation, Packaging Directive, Regulation (EU) 2019/631,
adopted in April 2019, which sets CO2 emission performance standards for passenger cars and light commercial vehicles.

In 2021, the European Commission adopted the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive ("CSRD") in line
with the commitment made under the European Green Deal. The CSRD, as further implemented by the EU Member States,
amended the existing Non-Financial Reporting Directive (NFRD) and will substantially increase reporting requirements
on the companies falling within its scope. With our application of the Global Reporting Initiative 2021 ("GRI 2021")
Standards and Disclosures that we use to report our sustainability-related data in a transparent and credible way, we believe
we are well prepared to meet CSRD's new reporting requirements.

In addition to our regulatory obligations, we leverage our quality, safety, and environmental certifications, which
we believe are an increasingly important factor in our customers' choice of rental partners. Our industrial, traffic services,
survey and laser and IQ-Pass brands are certified according to ISO 9001 standards. For Cramo entities in Sweden, Finland,
Norway, Estonia and Lithuania, we have been certified by ISO 9001, ISO 14001 and ISO 45001. All entities in the
Netherlands and Germany have ISO 50001 certification. In addition, IQ-Pass is ISO 27001 certified. In the UK, we are
audited by SafeHire and have met the bronze level requirements for Fors. Our Dutch (100%) and Belgian (60%) divisions
are VCA certified for Safety, Health and Environment, and the Dutch divisions have the Safety Culture Ladder Step 2
certificate for safety awareness.

_Corporate Social Responsibility_

We believe that sustainability primarily means striving for a safe and environmentally friendly fleet with a low
climate impact. In addition, health, safety, well-being, diversity and social and ethical issues are among our top priorities.
Our sustainability policy is comprised of three major ambitions:

    - we aim to become the most climate- and resource-efficient rental solutions company;


-----

    - we aspire to lead the way in advancing sustainability in the rental industry; and

    - we strive to lead our company with high business ethics.

We believe that our value chain perspective on sustainability helps us identify how we can optimally manage our
impact on the environment while optimizing our business. We also strive to meet our customers' increasing needs and
demands for more sustainable solutions.

To help achieve our sustainability goals, we have implemented internal processes, including the establishment of
a sustainability steering committee (the "Sustainability Steering Committee"). As part of these processes, we engage with
and work towards material topics, focus areas, strategic targets and targets per focus area, all of which are approved and
monitored by our Sustainability Steering Committee.

Based on a formal GRI 2021 materiality assessment conducted in 2022, we have identified four focus areas:
customer care, employee care, environmental care and social care, each of which we describe below. Our strategic targets
for each of these focus areas for 2025, in each case using 2021 as a baseline, involve:

    - achieving 85% of units powered by electricity within our energy powered fleet;

    - developing a harmonized group-wide customer satisfaction methodology;

    - reaching a 10% reduction of lost time injury rate, representing the average number of injuries occurring
over one million working hours, ("LTIR") per year;

    - attaining an employee satisfaction index of 84%;

    - reaching a wellbeing and diversity score of 80%;

    - achieving a 20% reduction in our Scope 1 and Scope 2 CO2 emissions (measured as tCO2/sales) (for the
year ended December 31, 2022, this amounted to 27.1 tCO2/sales, a decrease of 11% compared to 2021);

    - achieving a 15% reduction in our Scope 1 and Scope 2 energy use (measured as MWh/sales) (for the
year ended December 31, 2022, this amounted to €123 million per MWh, a decrease of 12% compared
to 2021);

    - increasing our share of renewable electricity use to above 92% (for the year ended December 31, 2022,
this amounted to 56%);

    - having over 75% of our group entities receiving a silver or higher rating from Ecovadis (relative to
revenue); and

    - reducing our exposure to legal proceedings pertaining to human rights, discrimination and sexual
harassment, environment and anti-corruption.

See "Risk Factors—Risks related to our Legal and Regulatory Environment—We are subject to risks related to
_environmental, social and governance matters, including the failure to meet certain of our targets."_

_Customer Care_

We believe that priority should always be given to our customers' sustainable operations. We strive to provide a
safe working environment at construction sites, digitalized solutions and high-quality rental equipment and services. We
also aim to help our customers minimize their climate impact by increasing circularity and offering an increased range of
resource-efficient and fossil fuel-free alternatives. Our focus in this respect therefore includes investing in modern, durable
and innovative technologies, in line with our aim to limit hazardous substances in our products and operations. Because of
our goals, we expect our suppliers and business partners to demonstrate similarly high ethical standards as ours.

We offer our customers a line of Eco-Label products, which currently consists of ecological alternatives to
commonly available fuel-powered machines. These sustainable options include either electric or battery driven products,
or products that have the capacity to significantly reduce fuel consumption and emissions. We offer our Eco-Label products
to assist customers in lowering their environmental footprint at construction sites and events. Eco-Label products also
produce less noise and vibration and meet high standards for safety and user-friendliness.


-----

In addition to expanding our sustainable service offering, Boels Training and Cramo Schools offer safety trainings
every year to our customers. Customers' safety is a top priority, and training programs help us prevent accidents at
construction sites by increasing safety awareness and competence.

_Employee Care_

We strive to offer safe and healthy workplaces for our employees. Our ultimate goal is to significantly reduce,
and if possible, eliminate, the occurrence of accidents within our control across our operations. We are also committed to
treating our employees in an open, honest and equal way and strive to provide a diverse and inclusive culture, where all
employees of different ages, gender and backgrounds have the same opportunities for development. In 2023, we have
created the diversity, equity and inclusion ("DEI") team to oversee our DEI initiatives, such as our leadership and talent
programs. We believe our workforce should reflect the diversities of the communities in which we operate, and as such we
strive to operate an unbiased recruiting process, remain committed to principles of fair pay and aim to consistently provide
promotional opportunities. In addition, we value competence-based training and support career growth that encourages
employees to achieve their full potential.

We maintain confidential reporting channels for our employees throughout our organization and are in the process
of harmonizing procedures following the Cramo acquisition, including through our group-wide business code of conduct
which is now in place. In our Nordic regions where Cramo operates, we have a whistleblowing channel whereby any
concern or issue regarding a potential compliance violation may be reported and investigated in a confidential manner. In
Central Europe, we operate our "Trust Persons" program whereby employees can report misconduct and receive guidance,
support and advice. A whistleblowing channel for Central Europe is expected launch in the near future.

Finally, the safety of our employees is of critical importance to us, and we invest heavily in safety trainings and
policies. Safety is a recurring topic in management sessions and is monitored through audits, inspections and reviews. For
the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2021, we had a LTIR of 16.2 and 17.4 injuries per one million working hours,
respectively.

_Environmental Care_

We continuously work to advance our capacities to mitigate our climate impact. In this respect, we focus on
finding ways to reduce our energy consumption, increase the use of renewable energy, and increase circularity of our
products across our operations. We also strive to use efficient logistics and transportation, reduce, reuse or recycle
materials, reduce waste, and handle hazardous waste properly. In terms of facilities, installations and vehicle fleet, we seek
to invest in energy-efficient products, services, and design for energy performance improvement.

_Social Care_

We strive to respect human rights throughout our entire value chain, and we support the Ten Principles of the
United Nations Global Compact, which we aim to incorporate throughout our business and processes. Furthermore, we
believe that an active collaboration with our customers, suppliers and other stakeholders is key to the further development
of sustainable rental solutions. We therefore endeavor, where possible, to take an active role in the communities in which
we operate and encourage our employees to do the same, such as by donating to local charities.

**Insurance**

We maintain the types of insurance and the insured sums customary in our industry and countries of operation.
To ensure we retain the coverage appropriate for our international operations, we use the advice and services of a network
of international and local insurance brokers in the countries in which we operate.

Our group insurance portfolio consists of international insurance programs with major insurance providers,
supplemented locally in certain countries where we operate. It is comprised, in particular, of our automotive fleet insurance,
general liability insurance, property insurance, accident insurance and cybercrime insurance. This set of tailored insurance
policies includes coverage for, among other things, occupational accidents and injuries, equipment, real estate and other
property damage or loss, cyber risks, and employers, product, public as well as directors and officers' liability insurance.

We consider our insurance coverage to be adequate both as to risks and sums insured for our business. Our
insurance portfolio is constantly reviewed for adequacy and adjusted if necessary. We have not had any material claims
that were not covered under our insurance policies.


-----

**Senior Facilities Agreement**

Boels Topholding B.V. as original borrower, original guarantor and company (the “Company”) is party to an
originally up to €1,788,000,000 senior facilities agreement (subsequently reduced to €1,629,300,000) originally dated
November 10, 2019 (as amended and restated from time to time including, most recently by the amendment and restatement
agreement dated June 15, 2021, the “Senior Facilities Agreement”) providing for a revolving credit facility in an aggregate
amount of €179,300,000 (the “Revolving Credit Facility”) and a term loan facility in a principal aggregate amount of
€1,450,000,000 (“Facility B”) (the Revolving Credit Facility and Facility B are collectively referred to as the “Senior
**Facilities” for the purposes of this description).**

Facility B was fully drawn prior to the issue date and must be repaid in full on the termination date, being February
6, 2027. The Revolving Credit Facility may be drawn by the Company and any additional borrowers which may accede to
the Senior Facilities Agreement subject to the conditions set out therein from February 6, 2020 (the “Closing Date”) up to
and including the date falling one month prior to the termination date. The Revolving Credit Facility will mature on the
date falling six years and six months after the Closing Date, being on or around August 6, 2026. The purpose of the
Revolving Credit Facility is to finance general corporate and working capital purposes of the Group including, without
limitation, financing permitted acquisitions and permitted joint ventures, financing distributions and dividends which are
permitted subject to compliance with a leverage ratio test and financing restructuring costs. The Revolving Credit Facility
may be used for the drawing of loans in euro, or by way of ancillary facilities (in any other currency as agreed between the
relevant ancillary lender and the Company) by the relevant lenders thereunder or an affiliate of such lenders. Any loan
made available under the Revolving Credit Facility shall (subject to the operation of customary rollover mechanics) be
repaid on the last day of its interest period and all amounts outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid
on the termination date applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility.

In addition to the Revolving Credit Facility and Facility B, the Senior Facilities Agreement includes (in addition
to other permissions under the limitation on indebtedness covenant) the ability to incur additional indebtedness (including
under one or more uncommitted additional facilities within the Senior Facilities Agreement and/or any additional notes
and/or other facilities or notes documented outside the Senior Facilities Agreement), provided that certain conditions are
met including (a) a €25,000,000 minimum amount for uncommitted facility commitments and (b) a pro forma incurrence
cap equal to the aggregate of: (i) the greater of (A) €205,400,000 and (B) an amount equal to 50 per cent. of Adjusted
EBITDA preceding the date of incurrence (after giving pro forma effect to the relevant transaction); plus (ii) an unlimited
amount at any time, where (A) Senior Secured Net Leverage (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) would not
exceed 3.54:1 where the relevant Financial Indebtedness (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) constitutes Senior
Facility Liabilities (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) or (B) in respect of Financial Indebtedness that does not
constitute Senior Facility Liabilities and, (I) is unsecured, Fixed Charge Cover (as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) would not be less than 2.00:1; and (II) is secured by Permitted Security (as defined in the Senior Facilities
Agreement) on a junior-ranking basis on assets which are also encumbered by Transaction Security securing Senior Facility
Liabilities on a senior-ranking basis; and/or encumbering assets which are not subject to Transaction Security, Total Net
Leverage (as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) would not exceed 4.83:1 or (C) solely in respect of acquisition
indebtedness (and including any available but undrawn commitments thereof), (I) Senior Secured Net Leverage (in respect
of Financial Indebtedness constituting Senior Facility Liabilities); or (II) Total Net Leverage and Fixed Charge Cover (in
respect of other Financial Indebtedness), would not be increased or decreased (as applicable) (each as defined in the Senior
Facilities Agreement), plus (iii) other than to the extent funded by long term financial indebtedness, the amount equal to
certain voluntary prepayments, permanent cancellations and repurchases by a member of the Group of the facilities incurred
under the Senior Facilities Agreement which constitutes a permitted debt purchase transaction thereunder, other permitted
facilities or notes incurred which are documented outside the Senior Facilities Agreement, together with all voluntary
prepayments of the revolving facilities incurred under the Senior Facilities Agreement to the extent accompanied by a
permanent reduction in the corresponding commitments.

**_Ancillary facilities_**

Under the Revolving Credit Facility, a lender (or an affiliate of a lender) may make available an ancillary facility
by way of an overdraft facility, a guarantee, bonding, documentary or stand-by letter of credit facility, a short term loan
facility, a derivatives facility, a foreign exchange facility, or any other facility or accommodation which is agreed by the
Company and the relevant ancillary lender, to a borrower in place of all or part of the respective lender’s unutilized
Revolving Credit Facility commitment.


-----

**_Interest and fees_**

The Senior Facilities bear interest at a rate of EURIBOR plus the applicable margin. The margin applicable to
the Senior Facilities is adjusted from time to time, subject to certain conditions (including but not limited to, if an event of
default under certain clauses has occurred and is continuing, the highest margin being payable) to a percentage rate per
annum determined in accordance with a Senior Secured Net Leverage related margin grid, such Senior Secured Net
Leverage as calculated and certified in each quarterly compliance certificate which is required to be delivered to the Agent.

If EURIBOR is less than zero, EURIBOR shall be deemed to be zero in respect of any loan made under the Senior
Facilities Agreement. Default interest is 1.00% per annum higher than the interest rate that would otherwise be applicable
in respect of the unpaid amount.

We are required to pay quarterly in arrears a commitment fee on the available but undrawn commitments under
the Revolving Credit Facility at a rate of 35% of the then applicable margin for the period commencing on the Closing
Date (February 6, 2020) and ending on the last day of the availability period applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility
(July 6, 2026) being the date falling one month prior to the termination date applicable to the Revolving Credit Facility (or,
if earlier, the date on which the Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full).

We are not required to pay any commitment fees to a lender for so long as it is a defaulting lender.

We are also required to pay certain fees to the facility agent and the security agent in connection with the Senior
Facilities Agreement.

**_Guarantees and security_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement is guaranteed by the Company, and certain other members of the Group (as
defined below) and is secured by the same Collateral that will secure the Notes and the Notes Guarantees, in each case
subject to certain limitations due to applicable corporate law and contractual provisions. In addition, the Senior Facilities
Agreement currently benefits from residual pledges over the share capital of certain non-material subsidiaries in Austria,
Poland, Italy and the Czech Republic, and security over certain bank accounts and certain intercompany receivables of said
non-material subsidiary in the Czech Republic, that previously guaranteed the Senior Facilities Agreement, that will not
secure the Notes. The Issuer may seek majority lender consent pursuant to the terms of the Existing Senior Facilities
Agreement to release such security at a future date.

The Senior Facilities Agreement further provides that the aggregate of earnings before interest, tax, depreciation
and amortization of the Company and all other guarantors with positive EBITDA (calculated on the same basis as EBITDA
(as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement), before reallocation of intra-group items, in each case evidenced on the
basis of the latest audited consolidated financial statements of the Company and its subsidiaries (in this description of the
Senior Facilities Agreement, will be referred to as the “Group”)) must represent at least 80% of the aggregate EBITDA
(as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) of the Group (before reallocation of intra-group items) determined annually
on the basis of the audited consolidated annual financial statements of the Group but in each case excluding any members
of the Group incorporated in an Excluded Jurisdiction (as defined below) and members of the Group with negative EBITDA
(the “Guarantor Coverage Test”). No breach of the Guarantor Coverage Test will occur if within the agreed accession
period, the Company procures that, subject to certain agreed security principles, additional members of the Group become
guarantors under the Senior Facilities Agreement such that if they had been guarantors under the Senior Facilities
Agreement on the reference date, the Guarantor Coverage Test would have been satisfied. The Guarantor Coverage Test
will be tested annually as per the end of each financial year of the Company. The agreed accession period is 120 days and
commences with the earlier of (i) receipt by the agent of the relevant annual financial statements and (ii) the date on which
the annual financial statements are due to be delivered. Additionally, the Company must procure that each member of the
Group which becomes, or any company acquired by a member of the Group which is, a Material Company (as defined in
the Senior Facilities Agreement) becomes a guarantor under the Senior Facilities Agreement and grants security as soon as
reasonably practicable and in any event within 120 days of such company becoming a Material Company, or, as the case
may be, being acquired.

“Excluded Jurisdiction” means Russia, Ukraine or any (other) Sanctioned Country (as defined in the Senior
Facilities Agreement).

**_Voluntary cancellation and prepayment and mandatory prepayment_**

The Company may, if it gives the facility agent at least five business days prior written notice, cancel the whole
or, subject to a certain minimum cancellation amount, part of an available facility under the Senior Facilities Agreement.
Any such cancellation will reduce the commitments of the lenders under the affected facility ratably.


-----

Each borrower may voluntarily prepay all or, subject to a certain minimum repayment amount, part of a utilization
made available to it under the facilities under the Senior Facilities Agreement by giving at least three business days prior
notice to the facility agent. Amounts prepaid in respect of Facility B under the Senior Facilities Agreement may not be
reborrowed as the relevant commitments will be irrevocably cancelled. Any prepayment shall be made with accrued
interest on the amount prepaid and, subject to breakage costs, without premium or penalty. Any such prepayment will be
shared pro rata across the lenders under the affected facility under the Senior Facilities Agreement.

In addition to voluntary prepayments, the Senior Facilities Agreement requires mandatory prepayment and
cancellation of the Senior Facilities:

    - with respect to any lender, if it becomes unlawful in any applicable jurisdiction for such lender to perform
any of its obligations, or to fund, issue or maintain its participation in any loan made available, under the
Senior Facilities Agreement (or it becomes unlawful for any affiliate of a lender for that lender to do so);
and

    - if a Change of Control or Sale (each as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) has occurred, with
respect to any lender that requires prepayment within a 30-business day offer period commencing on the
earlier of (i) the Company notifying the Agent of the event and (ii) the date on which the Lender becomes
aware of the event. Subject to the timely exercise of its rights within such offer period, each lender will
be entitled to require each borrower to repay such lender’s participation in any utilizations to that
borrower together with accrued and unpaid interest and any additional amounts accrued under the finance
documents.

Following the election of any lender to have its participation in any utilizations prepaid and cancelled following a
Change of Control or Sale, the facility agent shall by not less than 30 days’ notice to the Company cancel the commitments
of that lender and declare the participation of that lender in all outstanding utilizations, together with accrued interest and
all other amounts accrued under the finance documents to that lender, immediately due and payable.

Subject to the provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement (where applicable), the Company must further ensure that
the borrowers prepay loans and cancel available commitments in amounts equal to the applicable percentage (determined
based on the Senior Secured Net Leverage) of certain disposal proceeds, listing process and excess cashflow to the extent
applicable and subject to further conditions.

**_Financial covenant_**

In respect of each quarter date, the Company is required to confirm whether or not the Total Net Leverage (each
as defined in the Senior Facilities Agreement) for the period of the most recent four consecutive financial quarters (subject
to certain provisions and adjustments) exceeds 6.58:1 (the “Financial Covenant”).

A breach of the Financial Covenant will be deemed cured if it is complied with when tested on the next quarter
date and no notice of acceleration has been provided to the Company under the Senior Facilities Agreement in respect of
that breach of the Financial Covenant prior to such quarter date.

The Company is permitted to prevent or cure breaches of the Financial Covenant by electing to designate the
proceeds from any new equity of the Company and new shareholder loans received by the Company as a cure amount. The
Company may not make such election (i) more than four times during the life of the Senior Facilities Agreement (of which
no more than two times may be EBITDA cures), or (ii) in consecutive testing periods. Moreover, in each period of four
consecutive quarters there must be at least two quarters without a cure. A breach of the Financial Covenant may only be
cured if the relevant equity or shareholder loan is actually received by the Company no later than twenty (20) Business
Days after the date on which the relevant compliance certificate disclosing the breach was required to be delivered to the
facility agent.

**_General undertakings_**

We are subject to certain restrictive and, as the case may be, affirmative covenants under the Senior Facilities

will, in particular and without limitation, include restrictions and limitations (subject to exceptions, baskets and thresholds)
on:

    - Mergers, amalgamations, demergers, consolidations or other corporate reorganisations;

    - Acquisitions and joint ventures;

    - Disposals;

    - Share capital.

**_Events of default_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement contains certain events of default that are customary for such types of financing
(subject to customary materiality qualifications and grace periods), including, without limitation: (i) non-payment of

(iii) breach of other obligations, (iv) misrepresentations, (v) cross default or cross acceleration, (vi) insolvency or

cessation of business, (xiii) audit qualification, (xiv) judgment, (xv) litigation, (xvi) expropriation and (xvii) occurrence of
a material adverse change. The occurrence of any such event of default would, subject to any applicable grace periods or
cure rights and agreed exceptions, entitle the facility agent (and the facility agent must do so if so directed by the Majority
Lenders) by notice to the Company to (among other things): cancel their commitments, declare that all or part of the loans
together with accrued interest and all other amounts accrued or outstanding under the finance documents be immediately
due and payable and declare that all or any part of the amounts (including cash cover in respect of any outstanding amounts
under the ancillary facilities) is immediately due and payable or payable on demand.

**_Governing law_**

The Senior Facilities Agreement and any non-contractual obligations arising out of or in connection with it are
